				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Undergraduate Concentration in Gender &amp; Sexuality Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-439" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <div class="second-column column main-column" id="body-content">
<div class="clear-block">
<div class="content">
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/5D3_4003 smaller.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="114" /></span>Gender and Sexuality Studies is an interdisciplinary   concentration  that examines the construction of gender and sexuality in  social,   cultural, political, economic, or scientific contexts. Each  concentrator  will  focus on a well-defined topic or question and work  closely with a  concentration  advisor to develop  a program that  investigates this focus area rigorously and  supplements  it with  foundational courses in the relevant disciplines. <br /><br />Typical   areas of  focus might include the acculturation of gender, sexuality and  race in   American politics or activism; the construction  of sexual and  gendered  identities in educational institutions or in  various forms of  visual media; a  contrast between different cultural  understandings of  sexual identity, a particular  national literature  and history. Such  topics will frequently bring questions of  gender and  sexuality  together; however students may also organize their   concentrations to  emphasize questions specifically related to gender or  to  sexuality if  they wish. Introductory and methodology courses in  the disciplines   appropriate to students' focus will help them  understand the principles   grounding such practices as historical  research, literary  interpretation, and  sociological analysis.</p>
<p class="large"><strong><span class="style3 style4">Concentration Overview</span></strong></p>
<p>The concentration consists of 10 courses, 12 for honors  concentrators.</p>
<p>Requirements:</p>
<ul>
<li>GNSS0120: Introduction to Gender and Sexuality  Studies</li>
<li>Four-course focus on some thematic, theoretical or  historical aspect of gender and sexuality</li>
<li>Two introductory or methodology courses in  disciplines pertinent to the focus</li>
<li>One course in gender history, women's history, or  history of sexuality.</li>
<li>One course in feminist theory or theory of sexuality</li>
<li>A senior seminar which counts as your capstone course.  Senior seminar participants are expected to write a research essay</li>
<li>Prior to Commencement, all graduating senior concentrators are   required  to do a short presentation of either their senior essay or   thesis project</li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px">For further information, contact the director of Gender and Sexuality Studies:</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><strong>Drew Walker</strong><br />194 Meeting Street, Room 202<br />401-863-3585<br /> <a href="mailto:Drew_Walker@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Drew_Walker@Brown.edu</a></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">&nbsp;</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="image-clear"></div>  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

	</div>

</article>
							</div>

	<div id="calendar" class="clear-block block block-calwidget ">
	
	<h2>Calendar</h2>	
		<div class="content"><section class="events-list">
      <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Oct        </span>
        <span class="day">
          20        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b2132b0-000007c2events%40brown.edu/">Mid-semester deadline. Last day to change from credit to audit in a course (5:00 p.m. deadline).</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Oct        </span>
        <span class="day">
          23        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b2276fb-00000c48events%40brown.edu/">Advising period for spring pre-registration. Students in their first through third semesters will need to procure their advising PIN from their advisor in order to register.</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          02        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b22d593-00000eabevents%40brown.edu/">Date by which advisors must approve sophomore submitted concentrations in ASK to avoid having a "No Concentration" hold placed against the student's Banner registration (5:00 pm deadline)</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          07        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b241d24-000013fcevents%40brown.edu/">Registration for Semester II (Note: No student will be permitted to register for his or her fifth semester unless an approved declaration of concentration has been filed.)</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          10        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b23a96d-00001184events%40brown.edu/">Deadline for submission of proposals for undergraduate group study projects (GISPs) for Semester II</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          14        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b2477a0-000015e7events%40brown.edu/">End of the pre-registration period.</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          15        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5a4b500a-015a-4d117214-00006e4cevents%40brown.edu/">Registration for Wintersession courses (begins at 9:00 A.M.)</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          22        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b24cad2-000017c5events%40brown.edu/">Thanksgiving recess beginning Wednesday at noon</a>
          </li>
          </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul><!-- close out the last date -->
<div class="more-events">
  <span><a href="http://events.brown.edu/" class="more-link">View all calendars</a></span>
</div><!-- end .more-events -->


</section> <!-- end .events-list -->
</div>
			
				
	</div>

						</div><!-- end .third-column -->
							
				</div><!-- end .marginator -->
			</div><!-- end #content -->

			<section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">
				<div class="banner-text">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Previous Graduate Student Fellows</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-827" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p><strong><strong>2016-17 Graduate Student Fellows</strong></strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Arlen Austin, Modern Culture and Media </li>
<li>Noga Rotem, Political Science</li>
<li>Dan Ruppel, Theatre Arts and Performance Studies</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>2016-17 Interdisciplinary 6th-Year Graduate Fellows</strong><strong>&nbsp;</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Rama Srinivasan, Anthropology<strong></strong></li>
<li>Jerrine Tan, English</li>
</ul>
<p><strong><strong>2015-16 Graduate Student Fellows</strong></strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Kenneth Berger, Modern Culture and Media </li>
<li>Beth Capper, Modern Culture and Media</li>
<li>Joel Simundich, English</li>
<li>Dashiell Wasserman, English</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>2015-16 Interdisciplinary 6th-Year Graduate Fellows</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Bruno Penteado , Comparative Literature</li>
<li>Eleanor Skimin, Theatre Arts and Performance Studies</li>
</ul>
<ul>
</ul>
<p><strong>2014-15 Graduate Student Fellows</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Rebecca Haubrich, German Studies</li>
<li>Lilian Mengesha, Theatre Arts and Performance Studies</li>
<li>Michelle Rada, English</li>
<li>Seth Watter, Modern Culture and Media</li>
<li>Andrea Wright, Anthropology&nbsp;</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>2013-14 Graduate Student Fellows</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Ricarda Hammer, Sociology</li>
<li>Erin (Katie) Kahle, Slavic Languages</li>
<li>Kimberly Lewis, Anthropology</li>
</ul>
<table align="left">
</table>
  </div>

        </ul>

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Previous Undergraduate Fellows</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-828" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p class="small"><strong><span class="large">2016-2017 Undergraduate Fellows</span></strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Matthew De La Cruz, Comparative Literature, Philosophy</li>
<li>Danielle Gomez, Comparative Literature</li>
<li>Sophie Kasakove, Middle East Studies, Urban Studies</li>
<li>Joshua Kurtz, Religious Studies, Literary Arts</li>
</ul>
<p class="small"><strong><span class="large">2015-2016 Undergraduate Fellows</span></strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Tsvetomira Dumbalska, '16, Economics and Psychology</li>
<li>Elana Jaffe, '16, English</li>
<li>Peter Makhlouf, '16, Classics and Philosophy, Politics, Economics (P.P.E.)</li>
</ul>
<p class="small no-bullet roman-lower"><strong><span class="large">2014-2015 Undergraduate Fellow</span></strong></p>
<ul>
<li><span class="large"><span class="small">Shayna Zema, '15, Departments of Geography and Performance Studies</span></span></li>
</ul>
<p class="small"><strong><span class="large">2013-2014 Undergraduate Fellows</span></strong></p>
<ul>
<li>Oyinkansola Osobamiro,       '14, History and Program in Liberal Medical Education (PLME)</li>
<li>Margaret Tennis, '14, Anthropology and Slavic Studies</li>
<li>Ivan Yanev, '14, Political Science</li>
</ul>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

	</div>

</article>

</ul></div>
			
				
	</div>

				<div id="content">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Departmental Prizes</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-207" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h3><strong>For Undergraduate Students</strong></h3>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong>Ruth Simmons Prize in Gender and Women's Studies</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center is pleased and honored to offer the Ruth Simmons  Prize in Gender and Womenâs Studies. The prize is awarded annually for  an outstanding honors thesis on questions having to do with women or  gender. In the spring, the Pembroke Center invites faculty in all fields  to nominate honors theses for the prize. A committee of faculty who  teach and write in the area of gender studies will make the selection.<br /> <br /> If you wish to make a nomination, please send the following  to Box 1958 by 4:00 pm on current nomination deadline date:</p>
<ul>
<li>thesis  adviserâs evaluation</li>
<li>a  copy of the thesis</li>
</ul>
<p>The Ruth Simmons Prize carries with it an award of $1,000.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/Simmons%20prize%20recipients_4.pdf">Full list of recipients of the Ruth Simmons Prize in Gender and Women's Studies</a></p>
<p class="style1"><strong><a name="Abey"></a>Congratulations to the 2017 Ruth Simmons Prize  recipient<br /></strong></p>
<p class="style1"><strong>Rebecca Hansen<br /></strong>Department of English<br />Nonfiction Writing Honors Program</p>
<p class="style1"><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Rebecca Hansen.thumbnail.jpeg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></p>
<p class="style1">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="style1">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="style1"><strong><br /><br /></strong><em>"On Coming Forward"</em></p>
<p class="style1"><em>On Coming Forward</em>&nbsp;parses our relationship to shared, public narratives of pain, from a 1682 Puritan captivity narrative to the artwork of Emma Sulkowicz. Hansen interrogates the notion that such narratives necessarily serve a therapeutic or progressive function, arguing instead that they often reinforce the existing social ethos by framing injustice as a matter of personal, private trauma. In the end, Hansen seeks a new model for healing, one that does not require public testimony or social recognition.&nbsp;<em><br /></em></p>
<p class="style1"><em> </em></p>
<hr />
<p><em> </em></p>
<p><strong>Joan Wallach Scott Prize</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center for Teaching and Research on Women annually  awards the Joan Wallach Scott Prize for an outstanding honors thesis in  Gender and Sexuality Studies. Joan Wallach Scott is the Harold F. Linder  Professor of Social Science at the Institute for Advanced Study. Among  her many books are <span style="text-decoration:underline">Gender and the Politics of History</span> (1988), <span style="text-decoration:underline">Only Paradoxes to Offer: French Feminists and the Rights of Man</span> (1996), <span style="text-decoration:underline">ParitÃ©: Sexual Equality and the Crisis of</span> <span style="text-decoration:underline">French Universalism</span> (2005), and <span style="text-decoration:underline">The Politics of the Veil</span>: <span style="text-decoration:underline">Banning Islamic Headscarves in French Public Schools</span> (2007). Professor Scott taught at Brown from 1980-1985, where she was  Nancy Duke Lewis Professor and Professor of History. She was the  founding director of the Pembroke Center.</p>
<p>Each year the Pembroke Center awards this prize for an outstanding  thesis by a Gender and Sexuality Studies Concentrator.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/JWS%20prize%20recipients_1.pdf">Click for a list of all Joan Wallach Scott Prize recipients</a></p>
<div style="margin-left:40px"></div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h3><strong><a name="gradprize"></a>For Graduate Students</strong></h3>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong> Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center for Teaching  and Research on Women annually awards the Marie J. Langlois Dissertation  Prize for an outstanding dissertation in the area of feminist studies.  Marie J. Langlois became a trustee emerita of the Corporation in 2007    having previously served as trustee and vice chancellor of the    University since 1998.&nbsp; She served as a member of the Board of Fellows    from 1992 to 1998, as a member of the Board of Trustees from 1980 to    1985, and as a trustee and treasurer of the University from 1988 to    1992. She received a bachelor of arts degree from Brown in 1964 and a    master of business administration degree from Harvard University in    1967. Ms. Langlois recently retired as managing director of Washington    Trust Investors, a division of Washington Trust Company.&nbsp; She currently    serves on the boards of directors of the Rhode Island Foundation,    Lifespan, Salve Regina University, Rhode Island Philharmonic and Music    School, and Rhode Island Public Radio.</p>
<p>Each year the Pembroke Center awards this prize for a  dissertation in areas related to gender studies or feminist analysis. If  you wish to nominate a dissertation, please send to Box 1958 by 4:00 pm on current  nomination deadline date (April 21):</p>
<ol></ol>
<ul>
<li>A nominating letter including a brief description of the dissertation</li>
<li>A letter of support from a second member of the dissertation committee</li>
<li>A copy of the dissertation</li>
</ul>
<p>The Marie J. Langlois Prize carries with it an award of $1,000.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/Langlois%20Dissertation%20prize%20recipients_3.pdf">Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize recipients</a></p>
<p><strong><a name="Adler"></a>Congratulations to the 2017 Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize recipient</strong></p>
<p><strong><strong>Nicosia M. Shakes</strong><br /></strong>Africana Studies</p>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-none" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Nicosia Shakes portrait.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></p>
<p><em>âAfricana Womenâs Theatre as Activism: A Study of Sistren Theatre Collective, Jamaica and the Mothertongue Project, South Africaâ</em></p>
<p><span>The result of sixteen months of ethnographic research, Nicosia Shakesâ dissertation examines the activism of Sistren Theatre Collective in Jamaica and The Mothertongue Project in South Africa, two women-led organizations that use theatre to advocate for gender justice. Under the theoretical rubrics of Africana feminisms and activist aesthetics, Shakes analyzes how the two organizations transgress interlocking systems of gender, racial, sexual, and economic domination. She argues that Sistren and The Mothertongue exemplify the global interconnections between feminist activism and theory.</span></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong>Helen Terry MacLeod Prize</strong></p>
<p>From 1995-2007 the Pembroke Center awarded this prize for an  outstanding undergraduate honors thesis that addressed questions of  gender or women, or that brought a feminist analysis to bear on a topic  of study.</p>
<p><a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/MacLeodPrizeRecipients.pdf">MacLeod Prize recipients 1995-2007 </a></p>
<p>In 2007, this award was changed from a prize for a completed  honors thesis to a research grant available to support undergraduate  honors research. <a href="/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/research-grants-and-internships" title="Research Grants and Internships" rel="nofollow">See the grants page for more information.</a><span class="highlight">&nbsp;</span></p>
<div class="image-clear"></div><fieldset class="fieldgroup group-related-files"><legend>Related Files</legend><div class="field field-type-filefield field-field-related-files">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item odd">

              <div class="field-item even">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Departmental Prizes</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-207" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h3><strong>For Undergraduate Students</strong></h3>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong>Ruth Simmons Prize in Gender and Women's Studies</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center is pleased and honored to offer the Ruth Simmons  Prize in Gender and Womenâs Studies. The prize is awarded annually for  an outstanding honors thesis on questions having to do with women or  gender. In the spring, the Pembroke Center invites faculty in all fields  to nominate honors theses for the prize. A committee of faculty who  teach and write in the area of gender studies will make the selection.<br /> <br /> If you wish to make a nomination, please send the following  to Box 1958 by 4:00 pm on current nomination deadline date:</p>
<ul>
<li>thesis  adviserâs evaluation</li>
<li>a  copy of the thesis</li>
</ul>
<p>The Ruth Simmons Prize carries with it an award of $1,000.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/Simmons%20prize%20recipients_4.pdf">Full list of recipients of the Ruth Simmons Prize in Gender and Women's Studies</a></p>
<p class="style1"><strong><a name="Abey"></a>Congratulations to the 2017 Ruth Simmons Prize  recipient<br /></strong></p>
<p class="style1"><strong>Rebecca Hansen<br /></strong>Department of English<br />Nonfiction Writing Honors Program</p>
<p class="style1"><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Rebecca Hansen.thumbnail.jpeg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></p>
<p class="style1">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="style1">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="style1"><strong><br /><br /></strong><em>"On Coming Forward"</em></p>
<p class="style1"><em>On Coming Forward</em>&nbsp;parses our relationship to shared, public narratives of pain, from a 1682 Puritan captivity narrative to the artwork of Emma Sulkowicz. Hansen interrogates the notion that such narratives necessarily serve a therapeutic or progressive function, arguing instead that they often reinforce the existing social ethos by framing injustice as a matter of personal, private trauma. In the end, Hansen seeks a new model for healing, one that does not require public testimony or social recognition.&nbsp;<em><br /></em></p>
<p class="style1"><em> </em></p>
<hr />
<p><em> </em></p>
<p><strong>Joan Wallach Scott Prize</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center for Teaching and Research on Women annually  awards the Joan Wallach Scott Prize for an outstanding honors thesis in  Gender and Sexuality Studies. Joan Wallach Scott is the Harold F. Linder  Professor of Social Science at the Institute for Advanced Study. Among  her many books are <span style="text-decoration:underline">Gender and the Politics of History</span> (1988), <span style="text-decoration:underline">Only Paradoxes to Offer: French Feminists and the Rights of Man</span> (1996), <span style="text-decoration:underline">ParitÃ©: Sexual Equality and the Crisis of</span> <span style="text-decoration:underline">French Universalism</span> (2005), and <span style="text-decoration:underline">The Politics of the Veil</span>: <span style="text-decoration:underline">Banning Islamic Headscarves in French Public Schools</span> (2007). Professor Scott taught at Brown from 1980-1985, where she was  Nancy Duke Lewis Professor and Professor of History. She was the  founding director of the Pembroke Center.</p>
<p>Each year the Pembroke Center awards this prize for an outstanding  thesis by a Gender and Sexuality Studies Concentrator.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/JWS%20prize%20recipients_1.pdf">Click for a list of all Joan Wallach Scott Prize recipients</a></p>
<div style="margin-left:40px"></div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h3><strong><a name="gradprize"></a>For Graduate Students</strong></h3>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong> Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center for Teaching  and Research on Women annually awards the Marie J. Langlois Dissertation  Prize for an outstanding dissertation in the area of feminist studies.  Marie J. Langlois became a trustee emerita of the Corporation in 2007    having previously served as trustee and vice chancellor of the    University since 1998.&nbsp; She served as a member of the Board of Fellows    from 1992 to 1998, as a member of the Board of Trustees from 1980 to    1985, and as a trustee and treasurer of the University from 1988 to    1992. She received a bachelor of arts degree from Brown in 1964 and a    master of business administration degree from Harvard University in    1967. Ms. Langlois recently retired as managing director of Washington    Trust Investors, a division of Washington Trust Company.&nbsp; She currently    serves on the boards of directors of the Rhode Island Foundation,    Lifespan, Salve Regina University, Rhode Island Philharmonic and Music    School, and Rhode Island Public Radio.</p>
<p>Each year the Pembroke Center awards this prize for a  dissertation in areas related to gender studies or feminist analysis. If  you wish to nominate a dissertation, please send to Box 1958 by 4:00 pm on current  nomination deadline date (April 21):</p>
<ol></ol>
<ul>
<li>A nominating letter including a brief description of the dissertation</li>
<li>A letter of support from a second member of the dissertation committee</li>
<li>A copy of the dissertation</li>
</ul>
<p>The Marie J. Langlois Prize carries with it an award of $1,000.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/Langlois%20Dissertation%20prize%20recipients_3.pdf">Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize recipients</a></p>
<p><strong><a name="Adler"></a>Congratulations to the 2017 Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize recipient</strong></p>
<p><strong><strong>Nicosia M. Shakes</strong><br /></strong>Africana Studies</p>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-none" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Nicosia Shakes portrait.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></p>
<p><em>âAfricana Womenâs Theatre as Activism: A Study of Sistren Theatre Collective, Jamaica and the Mothertongue Project, South Africaâ</em></p>
<p><span>The result of sixteen months of ethnographic research, Nicosia Shakesâ dissertation examines the activism of Sistren Theatre Collective in Jamaica and The Mothertongue Project in South Africa, two women-led organizations that use theatre to advocate for gender justice. Under the theoretical rubrics of Africana feminisms and activist aesthetics, Shakes analyzes how the two organizations transgress interlocking systems of gender, racial, sexual, and economic domination. She argues that Sistren and The Mothertongue exemplify the global interconnections between feminist activism and theory.</span></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong>Helen Terry MacLeod Prize</strong></p>
<p>From 1995-2007 the Pembroke Center awarded this prize for an  outstanding undergraduate honors thesis that addressed questions of  gender or women, or that brought a feminist analysis to bear on a topic  of study.</p>
<p><a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/MacLeodPrizeRecipients.pdf">MacLeod Prize recipients 1995-2007 </a></p>
<p>In 2007, this award was changed from a prize for a completed  honors thesis to a research grant available to support undergraduate  honors research. <a href="/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/research-grants-and-internships" title="Research Grants and Internships" rel="nofollow">See the grants page for more information.</a><span class="highlight">&nbsp;</span></p>
<div class="image-clear"></div><fieldset class="fieldgroup group-related-files"><legend>Related Files</legend><div class="field field-type-filefield field-field-related-files">

			<header id="header-region">
				<section id="audience-gateways">
					<div class="marginator">

				<div id="brown-masthead">
				
					<div id="brown-brand">
						<div class="marginator">
							<h1><a href="http://www.brown.edu" accesskey="1" title="Brown University Homepage"><img src="/research/pembroke-center/sites/all/themes/ursa-minor/img/brown-logo.png" alt="" /><span>Brown University</span></a></h1>
							
								<div id="search-theme-form" class="clear-block block block-google_cse ">
										<form action="/research/pembroke-center/search/google" accept-charset="UTF-8" method="get" id="google-cse-searchbox-form">
											<input type="hidden" name="cx" id="edit-cx" value="001311030293454891064:lwlrsw9qt3o"  />

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Pembroke Center</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								<div class="view view-news view-id-news view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-1">
        <div class="view-header">
      <p>The Pembroke Center at Brown University is an interdisciplinary research center that fosters critical scholarship on questions of gender and difference, broadly defined, in national and transnational contexts.</p>
    </div>
  
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
          

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser  first-row">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-10/nicosia-shakes-16-am17-phd-receives-national-womens-studies-associationuniversity-illin">Nicosia Shakes '16 A.M.,'17 Ph.D. Receives the National Women's Studies Association/University of Illinois Press First Book Prize</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:173px;"><a href="http:/https://www.wooster.edu/bios/nshakes/"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Nicosia Photo.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="165" height="195" /></a></span>Nicosia Shakes '17 Ph.D., winner of the Brown University Joukowsky Award for Outstanding Dissertation and the Pembroke Center Marie J. Langlois Prize for Outstanding Dissertation in the area of Feminist Studies, has just been awarded the National Women's Studies Association/University of Illinois Press First Book Prize.</p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed October 16, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser ">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-09/pembroke-center-family-weekend-lecture-2017">Pembroke Center Family Weekend Lecture 2017</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p>Anna Aizer&nbsp;&nbsp;<span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Vulnerable Families.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="130" /></span><br />Professor of Economics &amp; Public Policy</p>
<p>Friday, October 13, 2017, 4:00 - 5:00 p.m.<br />Pembroke Hall 305<br /><br /></p>
<p><strong>Vulnerable Families in the (Un)Changing Economy</strong></p>
<p>Join the Pembroke Center for Teaching and Research on Women for a conversation with Professor Anna Aizer and Pembroke Center Associate Director and Director of Gender and Sexuality Studies, Drew Walker, about Professor Aizer's research on how gender and other issues of difference may influence labor, health and the intergenerational transmission of poverty.</p>
<p>This Family Weekend event is sponsored by the Pembroke Center Associates.<br />Free and open to the public. Handicapped accessible.</p>
<p></p><div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed September 27, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser ">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-09/pembroke-research-lecture">Pembroke Research Lecture</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Koven Lecture Image.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="130" /></span><strong></strong><strong></strong>Seth Koven<br />G.E. Lessing Distinguished Professor of History and Poetics, Rutgers University</p>
<p>Tuesday, October 10, 2017, 5:30 p.m.<br /> Pembroke Hall 305<br /><br /></p>
<p><strong>Queer Conscience, Straight State in WWI Britain</strong></p>
<p>Koven's talk focuses on one famously public-spirited gentry family, the Hobhouses, and the conscience of one man, Stephen Hobhouse, during WWI. Koven analyzes how, why and with what consequences Stephen Hobhouseâs mother, Margaret Potter Hobhouse, single-handedly orchestrated the warâs most successful campaign waged to save her oldest son Stephen, from a martyrâs death as an absolutist pacifist prisoner of conscience in 1917. Stephen's story reveals when and why the wartime state "queered" conscience and recasts the post-war disenfranchisement of conscientious objectors as an attempt to keep the state straight.</p>
<p>Koven's lecture supports our yearlong research seminar on "<a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/research-pembroke-center/pembroke-research-seminar">The&nbsp;Cultures of Pacifism</a>." </p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed September 13, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser ">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-07/2017-18-pembroke-research-seminar">2017-18 Pembroke Research Seminar</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p>The 2017-18 Pembroke Research Seminar, <a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/research-pembroke-center/pembroke-research-seminar">"The Cultures of Pacifism"</a>, is being led by <a href="https://vivo.brown.edu/display/lgandhi">Leela Gandhi</a>, <span class="display-title">John Hawkes Professor of the Humanities and English</span>.</p>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-middle" style="width:518px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Postdoc group w Leela.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-_original " width="510" height="359" /></span></p>
<p></p><div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed July 2, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser ">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-07/deadline-october-5-undergraduate-and-graduate-student-research-grants">Deadline October 5:  Undergraduate and Graduate Student Research Grants</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/ResearchStudents.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="131" /></span>The Pembroke Center invites applications from current Brown students, from any concentration or field, to apply for our research grants and internship. Undergraduate student grants are up to $1,000 and graduate student grants are up to $2,000.&nbsp; Please apply using <a href="https://ufunds.brown.edu/">UFunds</a> by Thursday, October 5, 2017.<a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/gender-and-sexuality-studies/research-grants-and-internships">&nbsp; Please see individual grant descriptions and guidelines</a>. </p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed July 1, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser ">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-06/2018-19-pembroke-research-seminar">2018-19 Pembroke Research Seminar</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p>Pembroke Center Postdoctoral Research Associate applications now being <span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/5DB_3287.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="130" /></span>accepted.</p>
<p>The 2018-19 Pembroke Research Seminar, <a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/future/pembroke-research-seminar">"What Are (Human) Rights? Imperial Origins, Curatorial Practices and Non-Imperial Ground"</a> will be led by Ariella Azoulay, Professor of Comparative Literature and Modern Culture and Media.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
<p></p><div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed June 27, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser ">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-06/graduate-certificate-gender-sexuality-studies">Graduate Certificate in Gender & Sexuality Studies</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/note_pad_pencil2_hires.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="129" /></span>The Pembroke Center is very pleased to announce the creation of a new <a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/gender-and-sexuality-studies/graduate-certificate-gender-sexuality-studies">Graduate Certificate Program in Gender and Sexuality Studies</a>. The graduate certificate enables graduate students already enrolled in PhD programs at Brown to develop methodological and theoretical expertise and credentials in the interdisciplinary field of gender and sexuality studies while fulfilling the graduate requirements of their degree-granting department. It will give students the opportunity for advanced training in the field; provide them with specialized professional training in Gender and Sexuality Studies; and foster a community of scholars dedicated to the study of the intersections of gender and sexuality and other related methodologies, such as critical race studies, cultural studies, legal theory, psychoanalytic theory, as well as more traditional disciplinary methods. </p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed June 15, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser ">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-06/black-feminist-theory-project">Black Feminist Theory Project</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p>The Pembroke Center is pleased to announce the appointment of Aneeka<span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Aneeka Henderson.thumbnail_0.jpg" alt="Aneeka Henderson" title="Aneeka Henderson"  class="image image-_original " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Aneeka Henderson</strong></span></span> Henderson as the 2017-18 Affiliated Scholar in Residence in the Black Feminist Theory Project. Launched in 2016-17, the new visiting scholar initiative invites a black feminist theorist to campus annually to contribute to the Pembroke Center's research and work with students, fellows, and faculty.</p>
<p><span>Professor Henderson is an assistant professor at Amherst College in the Sexuality, Womenâs and Gender Studies department. She is a 2017-2018 AAUW American Postdoctoral Fellow and a 2017 Woodrow Wilson National Foundation Career Enhancement Fellow. At Amherst College, she teaches a wide range of courses exploring a mosaic of African American literature, art, music, and film, and her classes have been featured in <em>Elle</em> magazine as well as the <em>New York Times</em>.</span></p>
<p>During her tenure, she will present a talk from her forthcoming book project, <em>Wedding Bell Blues: Race and the Modern Marriage Plot</em>, which examines ways in which contemporary music, film, and fiction negotiate and respond to complex neoliberal logics and black political nostalgia privileging marriage and family as supposed "cures" for inequality.</p>
<p><span>Envisioned as a site of intellectual collaboration across disciplines, the aim of the the Black Feminist Theory Project is to enhance the visibility and accessibility of black feminist discourse on campus as a resource for faculty, students, and the surrounding community, while calling attention to ongoing activism and interventions at the intersections of race, class, gender, sexuality, and public policy.<span>&nbsp; <a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/research/black-feminist-theory-project">Learn more about the project.</a> </span></span></p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed June 5, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    </div>

            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5a4b500a-015a-4d117214-00006e4cevents%40brown.edu/">Registration for Wintersession courses (begins at 9:00 A.M.)</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          22        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b24cad2-000017c5events%40brown.edu/">Thanksgiving recess beginning Wednesday at noon</a>
          </li>
          </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul><!-- close out the last date -->
<div class="more-events">
  <span><a href="http://events.brown.edu/" class="more-link">View all calendars</a></span>
</div><!-- end .more-events -->


</section> <!-- end .events-list -->
</div>
			
				
	</div>

						</div><!-- end .third-column -->

    </div><!-- End #wrapper -->

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Pembroke Center</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								<div class="view view-news view-id-news view-display-id-page_1 view-dom-id-1">
        <div class="view-header">
      <p>The Pembroke Center at Brown University is an interdisciplinary research center that fosters critical scholarship on questions of gender and difference, broadly defined, in national and transnational contexts.</p>
    </div>
  
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
          

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser  first-row">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-10/nicosia-shakes-16-am17-phd-receives-national-womens-studies-associationuniversity-illin">Nicosia Shakes '16 A.M.,'17 Ph.D. Receives the National Women's Studies Association/University of Illinois Press First Book Prize</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:173px;"><a href="http:/https://www.wooster.edu/bios/nshakes/"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Nicosia Photo.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="165" height="195" /></a></span>Nicosia Shakes '17 Ph.D., winner of the Brown University Joukowsky Award for Outstanding Dissertation and the Pembroke Center Marie J. Langlois Prize for Outstanding Dissertation in the area of Feminist Studies, has just been awarded the National Women's Studies Association/University of Illinois Press First Book Prize.</p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed October 16, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser ">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-09/pembroke-center-family-weekend-lecture-2017">Pembroke Center Family Weekend Lecture 2017</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p>Anna Aizer&nbsp;&nbsp;<span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Vulnerable Families.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="130" /></span><br />Professor of Economics &amp; Public Policy</p>
<p>Friday, October 13, 2017, 4:00 - 5:00 p.m.<br />Pembroke Hall 305<br /><br /></p>
<p><strong>Vulnerable Families in the (Un)Changing Economy</strong></p>
<p>Join the Pembroke Center for Teaching and Research on Women for a conversation with Professor Anna Aizer and Pembroke Center Associate Director and Director of Gender and Sexuality Studies, Drew Walker, about Professor Aizer's research on how gender and other issues of difference may influence labor, health and the intergenerational transmission of poverty.</p>
<p>This Family Weekend event is sponsored by the Pembroke Center Associates.<br />Free and open to the public. Handicapped accessible.</p>
<p></p><div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed September 27, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser ">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-09/pembroke-research-lecture">Pembroke Research Lecture</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Koven Lecture Image.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="130" /></span><strong></strong><strong></strong>Seth Koven<br />G.E. Lessing Distinguished Professor of History and Poetics, Rutgers University</p>
<p>Tuesday, October 10, 2017, 5:30 p.m.<br /> Pembroke Hall 305<br /><br /></p>
<p><strong>Queer Conscience, Straight State in WWI Britain</strong></p>
<p>Koven's talk focuses on one famously public-spirited gentry family, the Hobhouses, and the conscience of one man, Stephen Hobhouse, during WWI. Koven analyzes how, why and with what consequences Stephen Hobhouseâs mother, Margaret Potter Hobhouse, single-handedly orchestrated the warâs most successful campaign waged to save her oldest son Stephen, from a martyrâs death as an absolutist pacifist prisoner of conscience in 1917. Stephen's story reveals when and why the wartime state "queered" conscience and recasts the post-war disenfranchisement of conscientious objectors as an attempt to keep the state straight.</p>
<p>Koven's lecture supports our yearlong research seminar on "<a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/research-pembroke-center/pembroke-research-seminar">The&nbsp;Cultures of Pacifism</a>." </p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed September 13, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser ">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-07/2017-18-pembroke-research-seminar">2017-18 Pembroke Research Seminar</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p>The 2017-18 Pembroke Research Seminar, <a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/research-pembroke-center/pembroke-research-seminar">"The Cultures of Pacifism"</a>, is being led by <a href="https://vivo.brown.edu/display/lgandhi">Leela Gandhi</a>, <span class="display-title">John Hawkes Professor of the Humanities and English</span>.</p>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-middle" style="width:518px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Postdoc group w Leela.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-_original " width="510" height="359" /></span></p>
<p></p><div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed July 2, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser ">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-07/deadline-october-5-undergraduate-and-graduate-student-research-grants">Deadline October 5:  Undergraduate and Graduate Student Research Grants</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/ResearchStudents.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="131" /></span>The Pembroke Center invites applications from current Brown students, from any concentration or field, to apply for our research grants and internship. Undergraduate student grants are up to $1,000 and graduate student grants are up to $2,000.&nbsp; Please apply using <a href="https://ufunds.brown.edu/">UFunds</a> by Thursday, October 5, 2017.<a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/gender-and-sexuality-studies/research-grants-and-internships">&nbsp; Please see individual grant descriptions and guidelines</a>. </p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed July 1, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser ">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-06/2018-19-pembroke-research-seminar">2018-19 Pembroke Research Seminar</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p>Pembroke Center Postdoctoral Research Associate applications now being <span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/5DB_3287.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="130" /></span>accepted.</p>
<p>The 2018-19 Pembroke Research Seminar, <a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/future/pembroke-research-seminar">"What Are (Human) Rights? Imperial Origins, Curatorial Practices and Non-Imperial Ground"</a> will be led by Ariella Azoulay, Professor of Comparative Literature and Modern Culture and Media.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
<p></p><div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed June 27, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser ">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-06/graduate-certificate-gender-sexuality-studies">Graduate Certificate in Gender & Sexuality Studies</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/note_pad_pencil2_hires.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="129" /></span>The Pembroke Center is very pleased to announce the creation of a new <a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/gender-and-sexuality-studies/graduate-certificate-gender-sexuality-studies">Graduate Certificate Program in Gender and Sexuality Studies</a>. The graduate certificate enables graduate students already enrolled in PhD programs at Brown to develop methodological and theoretical expertise and credentials in the interdisciplinary field of gender and sexuality studies while fulfilling the graduate requirements of their degree-granting department. It will give students the opportunity for advanced training in the field; provide them with specialized professional training in Gender and Sexuality Studies; and foster a community of scholars dedicated to the study of the intersections of gender and sexuality and other related methodologies, such as critical race studies, cultural studies, legal theory, psychoanalytic theory, as well as more traditional disciplinary methods. </p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed June 15, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    

<article class="content news_story clear-block teaser ">




	<h3 class="teaser-title"><a href="/research/pembroke-center/news/2017-06/black-feminist-theory-project">Black Feminist Theory Project</a></h3>




	<div class="teaser-content">
		<p>The Pembroke Center is pleased to announce the appointment of Aneeka<span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Aneeka Henderson.thumbnail_0.jpg" alt="Aneeka Henderson" title="Aneeka Henderson"  class="image image-_original " width="100" height="100" /><span class="caption"><strong>Aneeka Henderson</strong></span></span> Henderson as the 2017-18 Affiliated Scholar in Residence in the Black Feminist Theory Project. Launched in 2016-17, the new visiting scholar initiative invites a black feminist theorist to campus annually to contribute to the Pembroke Center's research and work with students, fellows, and faculty.</p>
<p><span>Professor Henderson is an assistant professor at Amherst College in the Sexuality, Womenâs and Gender Studies department. She is a 2017-2018 AAUW American Postdoctoral Fellow and a 2017 Woodrow Wilson National Foundation Career Enhancement Fellow. At Amherst College, she teaches a wide range of courses exploring a mosaic of African American literature, art, music, and film, and her classes have been featured in <em>Elle</em> magazine as well as the <em>New York Times</em>.</span></p>
<p>During her tenure, she will present a talk from her forthcoming book project, <em>Wedding Bell Blues: Race and the Modern Marriage Plot</em>, which examines ways in which contemporary music, film, and fiction negotiate and respond to complex neoliberal logics and black political nostalgia privileging marriage and family as supposed "cures" for inequality.</p>
<p><span>Envisioned as a site of intellectual collaboration across disciplines, the aim of the the Black Feminist Theory Project is to enhance the visibility and accessibility of black feminist discourse on campus as a resource for faculty, students, and the surrounding community, while calling attention to ongoing activism and interventions at the intersections of race, class, gender, sexuality, and public policy.<span>&nbsp; <a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/research/black-feminist-theory-project">Learn more about the project.</a> </span></span></p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>		<strong class="distributed-date">(Distributed June 5, 2017)</strong>
	</div>


</article>
    </div>

	</div>

				<div id="content">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Gender and Sexuality Studies Courses</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-4" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Students.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span><span class="small">Please visit&nbsp;</span><a class="small" href="https://selfservice.brown.edu/ss/twbkwbis.P_GenMenu?name=homepage" target="_blank">Brown's online course catalog</a><span class="small">&nbsp;for a complete listing of all classes offered.</span></strong></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>Fall Semester 2017</strong></p>
<table>
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Code</th>
<th>Title</th>
<th>Schedule</th>
<th>Instructor</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>GNSS1711<br /></td>
<td><a href="https://selfservice.brown.edu/ss/bwckctlg.p_disp_course_detail?cat_term_in=201610&amp;subj_code_in=GNSS&amp;crse_numb_in=1711">Speech and Silence, Trust and Fear: A Feminist Philosophical Inquiry into Sex Equality</a></td>
<td>M 3-5:30<br /></td>
<td>P. Foa<br /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>GNSS1721<br /></td>
<td><a href="https://selfservice.brown.edu/ss/bwckctlg.p_disp_course_detail?cat_term_in=201610&amp;subj_code_in=GNSS&amp;crse_numb_in=1721">Cinema's Bodies</a></td>
<td>T 4-6:30<br /></td>
<td>G. Koch<br /></td>
</tr>

<td>T. Thompson</td>
</tr>

<td>T 3-5:30</td>
<td>D. Davis</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>GNSS2010K</td>

</tr>

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate Studies </h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-440" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/note_pad_pencil2_hires.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="129" /></span><strong>Graduate Certificate Program in Gender and Sexuality Studies</strong></p>
<p><strong></strong>The graduate certificate program enables graduate students already enrolled in PhD programs at Brown to develop methodological and theoretical expertise and credentials in the interdisciplinary field of gender and sexuality studies while fulfilling the graduate requirements of their degree-granting department. It will give students the opportunity for advanced training in the field; provide them with specialized professional training in Gender and Sexuality Studies; and foster a community of scholars dedicated to the study of the intersections of gender and sexuality and other related methodologies, such as critical race studies, cultural studies, legal theory, psychoanalytic theory, as well as more traditional disciplinary methods.</p>
<p><strong>Certificate Requirements</strong><br />The requirements for Certificate Program include coursework, teaching or TAing a course relevant to gender and sexuality studies, and the presentation of a paper in our Graduate Student Colloquium.</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><strong>1. Courses (4 total)</strong> <br />Courses must be completed with at least a grade of B in each course and include:</p>
<p style="padding-left:60px">â¢	GNSS 2000 â <em>Method, Evidence, Critique: Gender and â¨Sexuality Studies across the Disciplines</em> (currently offered once per year)<br /><br />â¢	Three approved relevant electives (1000- or 2000-level) from across the university â¨curriculum</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><strong>2. Research Paper<br /></strong>Students must complete a research paper that reflects the student's training in the field, to be presented to the Graduate Colloquium in Gender and Sexuality Studies. The paper may be completed for a course or a draft dissertation chapter. The Graduate Colloquium consists of a core group of related faculty and graduate students enrolled in the certificate program.</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><strong>3. Additional Experience: Teaching or Proctorship</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:60px">â¢	The teaching requirement can be met by teaching one's own seminar on a relevant â¨theme or TAing for the <em>Introduction to Gender and Sexuality Studies </em>or another approved course in Gender and Sexuality Studies. For students whose funding precludes their serving as teaching assistants, instructors, or proctors, appropriate accommodations will be made.<br /><br />â¢	Upon approval, students may fulfill the additional requirement with a semester-long proctorship in the Pembroke Center Archives instead of the teaching component. Students must demonstrate an intellectual and professional rationale for a proctorship in lieu of teaching.<span> <br /></span></p>
<p><strong>Application<br /></strong>Please apply to the GNSS Graduate Certificate Program using <a href="https://ufunds.brown.edu/">UFunds</a>.*<br />To access the application, log in to UFunds.&nbsp; After log in, please select "Doctoral Certificates," and then select "Gender and Sexuality Studies."</p>
<p>*Applications are accepted on a rolling basis.</p>
<p><strong>For More Information<br /></strong>Please contact <a href="Drew_Walker@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Drew Walker</a>, Director of the Gender and Sexuality Studies Program, to learn more about the graduate certificate.<span> <br /><strong><br />Additional Opportunities for Graduate Students</strong><br /></span></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center invites graduate students&nbsp; to apply for:</p>
<ul>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/gender-and-sexuality-studies/research-grants-and-internships#steinhauszisson">â¢ research grants</a></p>
<ul style="padding-left:30px">
</ul>
<ul style="padding-left:30px">
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/departmental-prizes#gradprize">â¢ dissertation prizes</a></p>
<ul style="padding-left:30px">
</ul>
<ul style="padding-left:30px">
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/research-pembroke-center/graduate-student-fellowships">â¢ fellowships</a> to participate in the <a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/research-pembroke-center/pembroke-research-seminar">Pembroke Seminar</a></p>
<ul>
</ul>
<div class="image-clear"></div>  </div>

			<section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate Studies </h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-440" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/note_pad_pencil2_hires.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="129" /></span><strong>Graduate Certificate Program in Gender and Sexuality Studies</strong></p>
<p><strong></strong>The graduate certificate program enables graduate students already enrolled in PhD programs at Brown to develop methodological and theoretical expertise and credentials in the interdisciplinary field of gender and sexuality studies while fulfilling the graduate requirements of their degree-granting department. It will give students the opportunity for advanced training in the field; provide them with specialized professional training in Gender and Sexuality Studies; and foster a community of scholars dedicated to the study of the intersections of gender and sexuality and other related methodologies, such as critical race studies, cultural studies, legal theory, psychoanalytic theory, as well as more traditional disciplinary methods.</p>
<p><strong>Certificate Requirements</strong><br />The requirements for Certificate Program include coursework, teaching or TAing a course relevant to gender and sexuality studies, and the presentation of a paper in our Graduate Student Colloquium.</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><strong>1. Courses (4 total)</strong> <br />Courses must be completed with at least a grade of B in each course and include:</p>
<p style="padding-left:60px">â¢	GNSS 2000 â <em>Method, Evidence, Critique: Gender and â¨Sexuality Studies across the Disciplines</em> (currently offered once per year)<br /><br />â¢	Three approved relevant electives (1000- or 2000-level) from across the university â¨curriculum</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><strong>2. Research Paper<br /></strong>Students must complete a research paper that reflects the student's training in the field, to be presented to the Graduate Colloquium in Gender and Sexuality Studies. The paper may be completed for a course or a draft dissertation chapter. The Graduate Colloquium consists of a core group of related faculty and graduate students enrolled in the certificate program.</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><strong>3. Additional Experience: Teaching or Proctorship</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:60px">â¢	The teaching requirement can be met by teaching one's own seminar on a relevant â¨theme or TAing for the <em>Introduction to Gender and Sexuality Studies </em>or another approved course in Gender and Sexuality Studies. For students whose funding precludes their serving as teaching assistants, instructors, or proctors, appropriate accommodations will be made.<br /><br />â¢	Upon approval, students may fulfill the additional requirement with a semester-long proctorship in the Pembroke Center Archives instead of the teaching component. Students must demonstrate an intellectual and professional rationale for a proctorship in lieu of teaching.<span> <br /></span></p>
<p><strong>Application<br /></strong>Please apply to the GNSS Graduate Certificate Program using <a href="https://ufunds.brown.edu/">UFunds</a>.*<br />To access the application, log in to UFunds.&nbsp; After log in, please select "Doctoral Certificates," and then select "Gender and Sexuality Studies."</p>
<p>*Applications are accepted on a rolling basis.</p>
<p><strong>For More Information<br /></strong>Please contact <a href="Drew_Walker@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Drew Walker</a>, Director of the Gender and Sexuality Studies Program, to learn more about the graduate certificate.<span> <br /><strong><br />Additional Opportunities for Graduate Students</strong><br /></span></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center invites graduate students&nbsp; to apply for:</p>
<ul>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/gender-and-sexuality-studies/research-grants-and-internships#steinhauszisson">â¢ research grants</a></p>
<ul style="padding-left:30px">
</ul>
<ul style="padding-left:30px">
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/departmental-prizes#gradprize">â¢ dissertation prizes</a></p>
<ul style="padding-left:30px">
</ul>
<ul style="padding-left:30px">
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/research-pembroke-center/graduate-student-fellowships">â¢ fellowships</a> to participate in the <a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/research-pembroke-center/pembroke-research-seminar">Pembroke Seminar</a></p>
<ul>
</ul>
<div class="image-clear"></div>  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">

				<div id="content">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Undergraduate Concentration in Gender &amp; Sexuality Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-439" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <div class="second-column column main-column" id="body-content">
<div class="clear-block">
<div class="content">
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/5D3_4003 smaller.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="114" /></span>Gender and Sexuality Studies is an interdisciplinary   concentration  that examines the construction of gender and sexuality in  social,   cultural, political, economic, or scientific contexts. Each  concentrator  will  focus on a well-defined topic or question and work  closely with a  concentration  advisor to develop  a program that  investigates this focus area rigorously and  supplements  it with  foundational courses in the relevant disciplines. <br /><br />Typical   areas of  focus might include the acculturation of gender, sexuality and  race in   American politics or activism; the construction  of sexual and  gendered  identities in educational institutions or in  various forms of  visual media; a  contrast between different cultural  understandings of  sexual identity, a particular  national literature  and history. Such  topics will frequently bring questions of  gender and  sexuality  together; however students may also organize their   concentrations to  emphasize questions specifically related to gender or  to  sexuality if  they wish. Introductory and methodology courses in  the disciplines   appropriate to students' focus will help them  understand the principles   grounding such practices as historical  research, literary  interpretation, and  sociological analysis.</p>
<p class="large"><strong><span class="style3 style4">Concentration Overview</span></strong></p>
<p>The concentration consists of 10 courses, 12 for honors  concentrators.</p>
<p>Requirements:</p>
<ul>
<li>GNSS0120: Introduction to Gender and Sexuality  Studies</li>
<li>Four-course focus on some thematic, theoretical or  historical aspect of gender and sexuality</li>
<li>Two introductory or methodology courses in  disciplines pertinent to the focus</li>
<li>One course in gender history, women's history, or  history of sexuality.</li>
<li>One course in feminist theory or theory of sexuality</li>
<li>A senior seminar which counts as your capstone course.  Senior seminar participants are expected to write a research essay</li>
<li>Prior to Commencement, all graduating senior concentrators are   required  to do a short presentation of either their senior essay or   thesis project</li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left:30px">For further information, contact the director of Gender and Sexuality Studies:</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><strong>Drew Walker</strong><br />194 Meeting Street, Room 202<br />401-863-3585<br /> <a href="mailto:Drew_Walker@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Drew_Walker@Brown.edu</a></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">&nbsp;</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="image-clear"></div>  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">

	</div>

</article>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduates from the Gender and Sexuality Studies Concentration</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">June 1, 2015</span>
</div>









	<div class="body">
		<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/5D3_4003 smaller.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="114" /></span>Congratulations to the Class of 2015. Graduates pictured (l-r): Katie Byron '15, Bennett Knox '15, Leigh Thomas '15, Ashleigh McEvoy '15. <br /><br />Missing from photo:&nbsp; Kyle Albert '15, Patricia Ekpo '15, Ariel Peak '15.</p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>	</div>

	




</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

		<div class="content"><div class="view view-contact-information view-id-contact_information view-display-id-block_1 view-dom-id-1">
    
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first views-row-last">
    <div class="vcard">
	<div class="adr">
		<div class="org">
		 <div class="organization-name">Brown University</div>

				<div id="brown-masthead">
				
					<div id="brown-brand">
						<div class="marginator">
							<h1><a href="http://www.brown.edu" accesskey="1" title="Brown University Homepage"><img src="/research/pembroke-center/sites/all/themes/ursa-minor/img/brown-logo.png" alt="" /><span>Brown University</span></a></h1>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">New Graduate Course: GNSS 2000 - Method, Evidence, Critique: Gender and Sexuality Studies across the Disciplines</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">January 12, 2016</span>
</div>









	<div class="body">
		<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/GNSS flyer graphic.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="98" /></span>Meets Tuesdays, 4:00-6:30 PM<br />Pembroke Hall 206<br />Instructor: Denise Davis</p>
<p>Gender and Sexuality Studies is by its very nature transdisciplinary.  Can we speak of a single methodology that ties GNSS together? How might  scholars work on gender and/or sexuality while respecting disciplinary  boundaries and training? We will start with the premise that studies in  gender and sexuality are tied together by critique that questions  foundational assumptions and takes account of its own position within a  given field of knowledge. By studying canonical theoretical texts  alongside disciplinary studies characterized by a feminist and/or queer  focus, we will investigate how critique operates and how standards of  evidence are marshaled in particular disciplines. <a href="https://selfservice.brown.edu/ss/bwckctlg.p_disp_course_detail?cat_term_in=201520&amp;subj_code_in=GNSS&amp;crse_numb_in=2000">See Banner listing here</a>. </p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>	</div>

	




</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
