				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">New Gender and Sexuality Studies Courses </h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">September 15, 2016</span>
</div>









	<div class="body">
		<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Roundtable Film.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span>The Pembroke Center is offering a number of new courses in Gender and Sexualilty Studies this semester. They include: "Local Color: Multi-Ethnic American Literature, 1880-1920," "Radical Italian Feminisms and the Contemporary Politics of Refusal," and "Convulsive Beauty: Hysteria and the Arts." &nbsp;<a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/courses-manual">Check out these and other courses, including a methods class for graduate students</a>.</p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>	</div>

	




</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

	<div id="pembroke-center" class="clear-block block block-menu ">
	
	<h5>Pembroke Center</h5>	
		<div class="content"><ul class="menu"><li class="leaf first menu-courses"><a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/courses-manual" title="">Courses</a></li>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate Certificate in Gender &amp; Sexuality Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">June 15, 2017</span>
</div>









	<div class="body">
		<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/note_pad_pencil2_hires.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="129" /></span>The Pembroke Center is very pleased to announce the creation of a new <a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/gender-and-sexuality-studies/graduate-certificate-gender-sexuality-studies">Graduate Certificate Program in Gender and Sexuality Studies</a>. The graduate certificate enables graduate students already enrolled in PhD programs at Brown to develop methodological and theoretical expertise and credentials in the interdisciplinary field of gender and sexuality studies while fulfilling the graduate requirements of their degree-granting department. It will give students the opportunity for advanced training in the field; provide them with specialized professional training in Gender and Sexuality Studies; and foster a community of scholars dedicated to the study of the intersections of gender and sexuality and other related methodologies, such as critical race studies, cultural studies, legal theory, psychoanalytic theory, as well as more traditional disciplinary methods.</p>
<p>The requirements for Certificate Program include coursework, teaching or TAing a course relevant to gender and sexuality studies, and the presentation of a paper in our new Graduate Student Colloquium. Please contact <a href="mailto:Drew_Walker@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Drew Walker</a>, Director of the Gender and Sexuality Studies Program, for more information.<span>&nbsp;</span></p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>	</div>

	




</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">

											<div id="sidebar-right" class="sidebar third-column column">
							
	
	<div id="calendar" class="clear-block block block-calwidget ">
	
	<h2>Calendar</h2>	
		<div class="content"><section class="events-list">
      <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Oct        </span>
        <span class="day">
          20        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b2132b0-000007c2events%40brown.edu/">Mid-semester deadline. Last day to change from credit to audit in a course (5:00 p.m. deadline).</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Oct        </span>
        <span class="day">
          23        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b2276fb-00000c48events%40brown.edu/">Advising period for spring pre-registration. Students in their first through third semesters will need to procure their advising PIN from their advisor in order to register.</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          02        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b22d593-00000eabevents%40brown.edu/">Date by which advisors must approve sophomore submitted concentrations in ASK to avoid having a "No Concentration" hold placed against the student's Banner registration (5:00 pm deadline)</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          07        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b241d24-000013fcevents%40brown.edu/">Registration for Semester II (Note: No student will be permitted to register for his or her fifth semester unless an approved declaration of concentration has been filed.)</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          10        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">

          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>

          14        </span></h5>

            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>

								</ul>
							</div>
							
							<div id="breadcrumbs"><ul>	<li class="first"><a tabindex="181" href="/research/pembroke-center/">Pembroke Center for Teaching and Research on Women</a></li>	<li><a tabindex="182" href="/research/pembroke-center/news">News</a></li>	<li class="last"><span class="a">Deadline October 5:  Undergraduate and Graduate Student Research Grants</span></li></ul></div>					</nav>
				</div>
					

				</div><!-- end #brown-masthead -->
				
                          
			</header>


		
					
			<section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">
				<div class="banner-text">
					<a href="/research/pembroke-center/" title="" style="height:200px;" class="bare-banner-link" accesskey="2"></a>				</div>
			</section>
			
		
<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Deadline October 5:  Undergraduate and Graduate Student Research Grants</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								

<article class="content news_story clear-block main-article">

<div class="p details">
    <span class="date">July 1, 2017</span>
</div>









	<div class="body">
		<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/ResearchStudents.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="131" /></span>The Pembroke Center invites applications from current Brown students, from any concentration or field, to apply for our research grants and internship. Undergraduate student grants are up to $1,000 and graduate student grants are up to $2,000.&nbsp; Please apply using <a href="https://ufunds.brown.edu/">UFunds</a> by Thursday, October 5, 2017.<a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/gender-and-sexuality-studies/research-grants-and-internships">&nbsp; Please see individual grant descriptions and guidelines</a>.</p>
<div class="image-clear"></div>	</div>

	




</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Graduate Student Fellowships</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-262" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p class="large"><strong>Graduate Student Fellowships<span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:203px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Conversation.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="195" height="130" /></span></strong></p>
<p><a href="#gradfellows" rel="nofollow">2017-2018 Graduate Student Fellows</a></p>
<p><a href="#interdisciplinaryfellows" rel="nofollow">2017-18 Interdisciplinary 6th-year Graduate Student Fellowship</a></p>
<p><a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/previous-graduate-student-fellows">Previous Graduate Student Fellows</a></p>
<p class="large"><strong>2018-2019 Graduate Student Fellowships</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center invites graduate students to participate as Fellows in the 2018-2019 Pembroke Seminar on <a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/future/pembroke-research-seminar">"What Are (Human) Rights? Imperial Origins, Curatorial Practices and Non-Imperial Ground"</a>.&nbsp;  Graduate student fellows will receive a stipend of $1,000 for two  semesters of participation. Applications are due by 4:00 pm on Thursday, March 15,  2018.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/future/pembroke-research-seminar">The Pembroke Seminar </a>is an  interdisciplinary research seminar  meeting weekly throughout the academic year. Graduate Fellowships  provide an enhanced context for advanced doctoral students, including  the opportunity for presentation of work and benefits or critique from  an exciting group of Pembroke Center Faculty Fellows, Postdoctoral  Fellows and distinguished Visiting Fellows. The Pembroke Research  Seminar meets on Wednesdays from 10:00 am - 12:30 pm.</p>
<p style="text-align:center">2018-2019 Seminar  topic:<a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/future/pembroke-research-seminar"><strong> <br /></strong></a><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/future/pembroke-research-seminar">"What Are (Human) Rights? Imperial Origins, <br />Curatorial Practices and Non-Imperial Ground"</a><a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/future/pembroke-research-seminar"><br /> </a>Seminar Director: Ariella Azoulay<a href="https://vivo.brown.edu/display/bhonig"></a></p>
<p class="large"><strong>There are two ways graduate students may participate in the  Pembroke Seminar:</strong></p>
<p class="large"><strong>Apply for  participation as a Graduate Student Fellow</strong></p>
<p>Graduate students who have  research interests related to the upcoming Pembroke  Seminar topic may submit a proposal. Up to three students will be  selected.  Each Graduate Student Fellow will receive a research stipend of  $1,000  for two semesters of participation. Graduate Student Fellows may also  receive  course credit (mandatory S/NC) by registering for GNSS2010L (Fall), and  GNSS2020L (Spring).&nbsp;</p>
<p class="large"><strong><strong>Request permission </strong>to  take the Pembroke Research Seminar for course credit</strong></p>
<p>A limited number of graduate  students may participate in the  Pembroke Seminar for course credit (mandatory S/NC). There is no stipend in this category  and instructor  permission is required. Graduate students with permission should register for GNSS2010L (Fall),  GNSS2020L (Spring).</p>
<p class="large"><strong>For 2018-19 Graduate Student Fellowship consideration, please submit  the following materials:</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>A       cover sheet indicating your name, current year, department, and (if relevant)       your dissertation director</li>
<li>A three-page, double spaced description of your research       project, including a brief representative bibliography</li>
<li>A brief letter of support from a faculty member       who knows your work</li>
</ul>
<p>Materials should be sent or delivered to Donna Goodnow, Pembroke  Center, Box 1958, 172 Meeting Street, Room 111, or emailed to <a href="mailto:Pembroke_Center@Brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Pembroke_Center@Brown.edu</a>. <br />The deadline for receipt  of materials is 4:00 pm on Thursday, March 15, 2018. <br />Call 863-2643, or email <a href="Mailto:Pembroke_Center@Brown.edu " rel="nofollow">Pembroke_Center@Brown.edu </a>with questions.</p>
<p><strong>Please note that there is no application form. Simply submit the materials indicated above.</strong></p>
<p class="large"><strong><a name="gradfellows"></a>The Pembroke Center Graduate Fellows for 2017 - 2018</strong></p>
<p><strong><strong>2017-18 Graduate Student Fellows</strong></strong></p>
<ul>
</ul>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td align="left" valign="middle"><strong><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:147px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Andersen.preview.jpeg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="139" height="195" /></span>Nicholas Andersen</strong><br /></strong>Religious Studies</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="left" valign="middle"><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:147px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Crucifix_0.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="139" height="195" /></span>Edwige Crucifix</strong><br />Comparative Literature<br /></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="left" valign="middle"><strong><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:147px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Rasch.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="139" height="195" /></span>Hilary Rasch</strong><br /></strong>English</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="left" valign="middle"><strong><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:147px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Thomas_0.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="139" height="195" /></span>Anna Thomas</strong><br /></strong>English</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><br /><a name="interdisciplinaryfellows"></a><strong class="large">Interdisciplinary 6th-Year Graduate Fellowships</strong></p>
<p>In 2015-2016, Brown began offering interdisciplinary  opportunities to support advanced graduate students. These opportunities  provide an enhanced context for advanced doctoral students, allowing  them to participate actively in the activities of interdisciplinary  Centers and Institutes at Brown.</p>
<p class="large"><strong>2017-18 Interdisciplinary Graduate Fellow at the Pembroke Center</strong></p>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td align="left" valign="middle">
<p><strong><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:147px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Kelow-Bennett.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="139" height="195" /></span>Lydia Kelow-Bennett</strong><br />Africana Studies</p>
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>

        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b22d593-00000eabevents%40brown.edu/">Date by which advisors must approve sophomore submitted concentrations in ASK to avoid having a "No Concentration" hold placed against the student's Banner registration (5:00 pm deadline)</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          07        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b241d24-000013fcevents%40brown.edu/">Registration for Semester II (Note: No student will be permitted to register for his or her fifth semester unless an approved declaration of concentration has been filed.)</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          10        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b23a96d-00001184events%40brown.edu/">Deadline for submission of proposals for undergraduate group study projects (GISPs) for Semester II</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          14        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b2477a0-000015e7events%40brown.edu/">End of the pre-registration period.</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          15        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5a4b500a-015a-4d117214-00006e4cevents%40brown.edu/">Registration for Wintersession courses (begins at 9:00 A.M.)</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          22        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b24cad2-000017c5events%40brown.edu/">Thanksgiving recess beginning Wednesday at noon</a>
          </li>
          </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul><!-- close out the last date -->
<div class="more-events">
  <span><a href="http://events.brown.edu/" class="more-link">View all calendars</a></span>
</div><!-- end .more-events -->


</section> <!-- end .events-list -->
</div>
			
				
	</div>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Undergraduate Fellowships</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-268" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p><strong><span class="large">Undergraduate Fellowships<span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-right" style="width:138px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Computer_0.preview.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-preview " width="130" height="195" /></span></span></strong></p>
<p><a href="#undergrads" rel="nofollow">2017-2018 Undergraduate Student Fellows</a></p>
<p><a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/previous-undergraduate-fellows">Previous Undergraduate Student Fellows</a></p>
<p class="large"><strong>2018-19 Undergraduate Fellowships</strong></p>
<p><span class="style1">The  Pembroke Center invites undergraduate  students to apply for participation as  Undergraduate Student Fellows in  the 2018-19 Pembroke Seminar</span>, <a class="small" href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/future/pembroke-research-seminar"><strong>&nbsp;</strong></a><strong class="small"><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/future/pembroke-research-seminar">"<span class="large small">What Are (Human) Rights? Imperial Origins, Curatorial Practices and Non-Imperial Ground"</span></a></strong><a class="small large" href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/future/pembroke-research-seminar"><strong>.</strong>&nbsp;</a> Selected students will receive a stipend of $1,000 for two semesters of  participation. Undergraduates who will be in their 5th semester or  above in the fall, and who have interests related to  the upcoming  seminar are invited to apply; a limited number will be selected.  Proposals are due by 4:00 pm on March 15, 2018.</p>
<p>The Pembroke Seminar is an interdisciplinary research seminar that  meets weekly throughout the academic year. Undergraduate Fellowships  provide an enhanced context for advanced honors students, including the  opportunity for presentation of work and benefits of critique from  Pembroke Center Faculty Fellows, Postdoctoral Fellows, Graduate Fellows,  and distinguished Visiting Fellows. The Pembroke Research Seminar meets  on Wednesdays from 10:00 am - 12:30 pm.</p>
<p><strong>There are  two ways undergraduate students may participate in the Pembroke Seminar:</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><strong>1) Apply for  participation as an Undergraduate Student Fellow</strong><br />Undergraduates who will be  in their 5th semester or above in the fall, and who have interests  related to the upcoming <a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/future/pembroke-research-seminar">Pembroke  Seminar</a> topic are invited to apply; a limited number will be  selected.  Undergraduate  Student Fellows may receive course credit (mandatory S/NC) by registering  for GNSS2010L (Fall),  GNSS2020L (Spring).</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"><strong>2) Request permission to take the Pembroke  Research Seminar for course credit</strong><br />A limited number of  undergraduate students may participate in the  Pembroke Seminar for course  credit (mandatory S/NC). There is no stipend in this   category and instructor permission is required. Undergraduate students  with permission  should register for GNSS2010L (Fall), GNSS2020L (Spring).</p>
<p><strong>For 2018-19 Undergraduate Student Fellowship  consideration, please submit the following:</strong></p>
<ul>
</ul>
<ol> </ol>
<p><span class="large">â¢</span>&nbsp; A cover sheet indicating your name, current  semester, concentration, campus box, email, and a brief description of your background<br /><span class="large">â¢</span>&nbsp; A three-page, double spaced, detailed discussion of your interest  in the topic<br /><span class="large">â¢</span>&nbsp; A brief letter of support from a faculty member who  knows your work</p>
<ul>
</ul>
<p>Proposals should be sent or delivered to Donna Goodnow,  Pembroke  Center, Box 1958, 172 Meeting Street, Room 111, or emailed to <a href="mailto:pembroke_center@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Pembroke_Center@Brown.edu</a>. <br /><br /><strong>The deadline for receipt  of materials  is 4:00 pm on Thursday, March 15, 2018. </strong><br />Please  call 863-2643, or  email <a href="mailto:Donna_Goodnow@Brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Pembroke_Center@Brown.edu</a> with questions.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/future/pembroke-research-seminar">(More application and deadline information)</a></p>
<p><a name="undergrads"></a><strong><span class="large">2017-2018 Undergraduate Fellows</span></strong></p>
<table>
<tbody>

</td>
</tr>

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Departmental Prizes</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-207" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h3><strong>For Undergraduate Students</strong></h3>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong>Ruth Simmons Prize in Gender and Women's Studies</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center is pleased and honored to offer the Ruth Simmons  Prize in Gender and Womenâs Studies. The prize is awarded annually for  an outstanding honors thesis on questions having to do with women or  gender. In the spring, the Pembroke Center invites faculty in all fields  to nominate honors theses for the prize. A committee of faculty who  teach and write in the area of gender studies will make the selection.<br /> <br /> If you wish to make a nomination, please send the following  to Box 1958 by 4:00 pm on current nomination deadline date:</p>
<ul>
<li>thesis  adviserâs evaluation</li>
<li>a  copy of the thesis</li>
</ul>
<p>The Ruth Simmons Prize carries with it an award of $1,000.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/Simmons%20prize%20recipients_4.pdf">Full list of recipients of the Ruth Simmons Prize in Gender and Women's Studies</a></p>
<p class="style1"><strong><a name="Abey"></a>Congratulations to the 2017 Ruth Simmons Prize  recipient<br /></strong></p>
<p class="style1"><strong>Rebecca Hansen<br /></strong>Department of English<br />Nonfiction Writing Honors Program</p>
<p class="style1"><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Rebecca Hansen.thumbnail.jpeg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></p>
<p class="style1">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="style1">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="style1"><strong><br /><br /></strong><em>"On Coming Forward"</em></p>
<p class="style1"><em>On Coming Forward</em>&nbsp;parses our relationship to shared, public narratives of pain, from a 1682 Puritan captivity narrative to the artwork of Emma Sulkowicz. Hansen interrogates the notion that such narratives necessarily serve a therapeutic or progressive function, arguing instead that they often reinforce the existing social ethos by framing injustice as a matter of personal, private trauma. In the end, Hansen seeks a new model for healing, one that does not require public testimony or social recognition.&nbsp;<em><br /></em></p>
<p class="style1"><em> </em></p>
<hr />
<p><em> </em></p>
<p><strong>Joan Wallach Scott Prize</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center for Teaching and Research on Women annually  awards the Joan Wallach Scott Prize for an outstanding honors thesis in  Gender and Sexuality Studies. Joan Wallach Scott is the Harold F. Linder  Professor of Social Science at the Institute for Advanced Study. Among  her many books are <span style="text-decoration:underline">Gender and the Politics of History</span> (1988), <span style="text-decoration:underline">Only Paradoxes to Offer: French Feminists and the Rights of Man</span> (1996), <span style="text-decoration:underline">ParitÃ©: Sexual Equality and the Crisis of</span> <span style="text-decoration:underline">French Universalism</span> (2005), and <span style="text-decoration:underline">The Politics of the Veil</span>: <span style="text-decoration:underline">Banning Islamic Headscarves in French Public Schools</span> (2007). Professor Scott taught at Brown from 1980-1985, where she was  Nancy Duke Lewis Professor and Professor of History. She was the  founding director of the Pembroke Center.</p>
<p>Each year the Pembroke Center awards this prize for an outstanding  thesis by a Gender and Sexuality Studies Concentrator.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/JWS%20prize%20recipients_1.pdf">Click for a list of all Joan Wallach Scott Prize recipients</a></p>
<div style="margin-left:40px"></div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h3><strong><a name="gradprize"></a>For Graduate Students</strong></h3>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong> Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center for Teaching  and Research on Women annually awards the Marie J. Langlois Dissertation  Prize for an outstanding dissertation in the area of feminist studies.  Marie J. Langlois became a trustee emerita of the Corporation in 2007    having previously served as trustee and vice chancellor of the    University since 1998.&nbsp; She served as a member of the Board of Fellows    from 1992 to 1998, as a member of the Board of Trustees from 1980 to    1985, and as a trustee and treasurer of the University from 1988 to    1992. She received a bachelor of arts degree from Brown in 1964 and a    master of business administration degree from Harvard University in    1967. Ms. Langlois recently retired as managing director of Washington    Trust Investors, a division of Washington Trust Company.&nbsp; She currently    serves on the boards of directors of the Rhode Island Foundation,    Lifespan, Salve Regina University, Rhode Island Philharmonic and Music    School, and Rhode Island Public Radio.</p>
<p>Each year the Pembroke Center awards this prize for a  dissertation in areas related to gender studies or feminist analysis. If  you wish to nominate a dissertation, please send to Box 1958 by 4:00 pm on current  nomination deadline date (April 21):</p>
<ol></ol>
<ul>
<li>A nominating letter including a brief description of the dissertation</li>
<li>A letter of support from a second member of the dissertation committee</li>
<li>A copy of the dissertation</li>
</ul>
<p>The Marie J. Langlois Prize carries with it an award of $1,000.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/Langlois%20Dissertation%20prize%20recipients_3.pdf">Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize recipients</a></p>
<p><strong><a name="Adler"></a>Congratulations to the 2017 Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize recipient</strong></p>
<p><strong><strong>Nicosia M. Shakes</strong><br /></strong>Africana Studies</p>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-none" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Nicosia Shakes portrait.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></p>
<p><em>âAfricana Womenâs Theatre as Activism: A Study of Sistren Theatre Collective, Jamaica and the Mothertongue Project, South Africaâ</em></p>
<p><span>The result of sixteen months of ethnographic research, Nicosia Shakesâ dissertation examines the activism of Sistren Theatre Collective in Jamaica and The Mothertongue Project in South Africa, two women-led organizations that use theatre to advocate for gender justice. Under the theoretical rubrics of Africana feminisms and activist aesthetics, Shakes analyzes how the two organizations transgress interlocking systems of gender, racial, sexual, and economic domination. She argues that Sistren and The Mothertongue exemplify the global interconnections between feminist activism and theory.</span></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong>Helen Terry MacLeod Prize</strong></p>
<p>From 1995-2007 the Pembroke Center awarded this prize for an  outstanding undergraduate honors thesis that addressed questions of  gender or women, or that brought a feminist analysis to bear on a topic  of study.</p>
<p><a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/MacLeodPrizeRecipients.pdf">MacLeod Prize recipients 1995-2007 </a></p>
<p>In 2007, this award was changed from a prize for a completed  honors thesis to a research grant available to support undergraduate  honors research. <a href="/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/research-grants-and-internships" title="Research Grants and Internships" rel="nofollow">See the grants page for more information.</a><span class="highlight">&nbsp;</span></p>
<div class="image-clear"></div><fieldset class="fieldgroup group-related-files"><legend>Related Files</legend><div class="field field-type-filefield field-field-related-files">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Departmental Prizes</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-207" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h3><strong>For Undergraduate Students</strong></h3>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong>Ruth Simmons Prize in Gender and Women's Studies</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center is pleased and honored to offer the Ruth Simmons  Prize in Gender and Womenâs Studies. The prize is awarded annually for  an outstanding honors thesis on questions having to do with women or  gender. In the spring, the Pembroke Center invites faculty in all fields  to nominate honors theses for the prize. A committee of faculty who  teach and write in the area of gender studies will make the selection.<br /> <br /> If you wish to make a nomination, please send the following  to Box 1958 by 4:00 pm on current nomination deadline date:</p>
<ul>
<li>thesis  adviserâs evaluation</li>
<li>a  copy of the thesis</li>
</ul>
<p>The Ruth Simmons Prize carries with it an award of $1,000.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/Simmons%20prize%20recipients_4.pdf">Full list of recipients of the Ruth Simmons Prize in Gender and Women's Studies</a></p>
<p class="style1"><strong><a name="Abey"></a>Congratulations to the 2017 Ruth Simmons Prize  recipient<br /></strong></p>
<p class="style1"><strong>Rebecca Hansen<br /></strong>Department of English<br />Nonfiction Writing Honors Program</p>
<p class="style1"><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Rebecca Hansen.thumbnail.jpeg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></p>
<p class="style1">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="style1">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="style1"><strong><br /><br /></strong><em>"On Coming Forward"</em></p>
<p class="style1"><em>On Coming Forward</em>&nbsp;parses our relationship to shared, public narratives of pain, from a 1682 Puritan captivity narrative to the artwork of Emma Sulkowicz. Hansen interrogates the notion that such narratives necessarily serve a therapeutic or progressive function, arguing instead that they often reinforce the existing social ethos by framing injustice as a matter of personal, private trauma. In the end, Hansen seeks a new model for healing, one that does not require public testimony or social recognition.&nbsp;<em><br /></em></p>
<p class="style1"><em> </em></p>
<hr />
<p><em> </em></p>
<p><strong>Joan Wallach Scott Prize</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center for Teaching and Research on Women annually  awards the Joan Wallach Scott Prize for an outstanding honors thesis in  Gender and Sexuality Studies. Joan Wallach Scott is the Harold F. Linder  Professor of Social Science at the Institute for Advanced Study. Among  her many books are <span style="text-decoration:underline">Gender and the Politics of History</span> (1988), <span style="text-decoration:underline">Only Paradoxes to Offer: French Feminists and the Rights of Man</span> (1996), <span style="text-decoration:underline">ParitÃ©: Sexual Equality and the Crisis of</span> <span style="text-decoration:underline">French Universalism</span> (2005), and <span style="text-decoration:underline">The Politics of the Veil</span>: <span style="text-decoration:underline">Banning Islamic Headscarves in French Public Schools</span> (2007). Professor Scott taught at Brown from 1980-1985, where she was  Nancy Duke Lewis Professor and Professor of History. She was the  founding director of the Pembroke Center.</p>
<p>Each year the Pembroke Center awards this prize for an outstanding  thesis by a Gender and Sexuality Studies Concentrator.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/JWS%20prize%20recipients_1.pdf">Click for a list of all Joan Wallach Scott Prize recipients</a></p>
<div style="margin-left:40px"></div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h3><strong><a name="gradprize"></a>For Graduate Students</strong></h3>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong> Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center for Teaching  and Research on Women annually awards the Marie J. Langlois Dissertation  Prize for an outstanding dissertation in the area of feminist studies.  Marie J. Langlois became a trustee emerita of the Corporation in 2007    having previously served as trustee and vice chancellor of the    University since 1998.&nbsp; She served as a member of the Board of Fellows    from 1992 to 1998, as a member of the Board of Trustees from 1980 to    1985, and as a trustee and treasurer of the University from 1988 to    1992. She received a bachelor of arts degree from Brown in 1964 and a    master of business administration degree from Harvard University in    1967. Ms. Langlois recently retired as managing director of Washington    Trust Investors, a division of Washington Trust Company.&nbsp; She currently    serves on the boards of directors of the Rhode Island Foundation,    Lifespan, Salve Regina University, Rhode Island Philharmonic and Music    School, and Rhode Island Public Radio.</p>
<p>Each year the Pembroke Center awards this prize for a  dissertation in areas related to gender studies or feminist analysis. If  you wish to nominate a dissertation, please send to Box 1958 by 4:00 pm on current  nomination deadline date (April 21):</p>
<ol></ol>
<ul>
<li>A nominating letter including a brief description of the dissertation</li>
<li>A letter of support from a second member of the dissertation committee</li>
<li>A copy of the dissertation</li>
</ul>
<p>The Marie J. Langlois Prize carries with it an award of $1,000.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/Langlois%20Dissertation%20prize%20recipients_3.pdf">Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize recipients</a></p>
<p><strong><a name="Adler"></a>Congratulations to the 2017 Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize recipient</strong></p>
<p><strong><strong>Nicosia M. Shakes</strong><br /></strong>Africana Studies</p>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-none" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Nicosia Shakes portrait.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></p>
<p><em>âAfricana Womenâs Theatre as Activism: A Study of Sistren Theatre Collective, Jamaica and the Mothertongue Project, South Africaâ</em></p>
<p><span>The result of sixteen months of ethnographic research, Nicosia Shakesâ dissertation examines the activism of Sistren Theatre Collective in Jamaica and The Mothertongue Project in South Africa, two women-led organizations that use theatre to advocate for gender justice. Under the theoretical rubrics of Africana feminisms and activist aesthetics, Shakes analyzes how the two organizations transgress interlocking systems of gender, racial, sexual, and economic domination. She argues that Sistren and The Mothertongue exemplify the global interconnections between feminist activism and theory.</span></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong>Helen Terry MacLeod Prize</strong></p>
<p>From 1995-2007 the Pembroke Center awarded this prize for an  outstanding undergraduate honors thesis that addressed questions of  gender or women, or that brought a feminist analysis to bear on a topic  of study.</p>
<p><a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/MacLeodPrizeRecipients.pdf">MacLeod Prize recipients 1995-2007 </a></p>
<p>In 2007, this award was changed from a prize for a completed  honors thesis to a research grant available to support undergraduate  honors research. <a href="/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/research-grants-and-internships" title="Research Grants and Internships" rel="nofollow">See the grants page for more information.</a><span class="highlight">&nbsp;</span></p>
<div class="image-clear"></div><fieldset class="fieldgroup group-related-files"><legend>Related Files</legend><div class="field field-type-filefield field-field-related-files">

	<div id="calendar" class="clear-block block block-calwidget ">
	
	<h2>Calendar</h2>	
		<div class="content"><section class="events-list">
      <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Oct        </span>
        <span class="day">
          20        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b2132b0-000007c2events%40brown.edu/">Mid-semester deadline. Last day to change from credit to audit in a course (5:00 p.m. deadline).</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Oct        </span>
        <span class="day">
          23        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b2276fb-00000c48events%40brown.edu/">Advising period for spring pre-registration. Students in their first through third semesters will need to procure their advising PIN from their advisor in order to register.</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          02        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b22d593-00000eabevents%40brown.edu/">Date by which advisors must approve sophomore submitted concentrations in ASK to avoid having a "No Concentration" hold placed against the student's Banner registration (5:00 pm deadline)</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          07        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b241d24-000013fcevents%40brown.edu/">Registration for Semester II (Note: No student will be permitted to register for his or her fifth semester unless an approved declaration of concentration has been filed.)</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          10        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b23a96d-00001184events%40brown.edu/">Deadline for submission of proposals for undergraduate group study projects (GISPs) for Semester II</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          14        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b2477a0-000015e7events%40brown.edu/">End of the pre-registration period.</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          15        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5a4b500a-015a-4d117214-00006e4cevents%40brown.edu/">Registration for Wintersession courses (begins at 9:00 A.M.)</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>
        <span class="day">
          22        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b24cad2-000017c5events%40brown.edu/">Thanksgiving recess beginning Wednesday at noon</a>
          </li>
          </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul><!-- close out the last date -->
<div class="more-events">
  <span><a href="http://events.brown.edu/" class="more-link">View all calendars</a></span>
</div><!-- end .more-events -->


</section> <!-- end .events-list -->
</div>
			
				
	</div>

						</div><!-- end .third-column -->
							
				</div><!-- end .marginator -->
			</div><!-- end #content -->


	

    </div><!-- End #wrapper -->

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Departmental Prizes</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-207" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <h3><strong>For Undergraduate Students</strong></h3>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong>Ruth Simmons Prize in Gender and Women's Studies</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center is pleased and honored to offer the Ruth Simmons  Prize in Gender and Womenâs Studies. The prize is awarded annually for  an outstanding honors thesis on questions having to do with women or  gender. In the spring, the Pembroke Center invites faculty in all fields  to nominate honors theses for the prize. A committee of faculty who  teach and write in the area of gender studies will make the selection.<br /> <br /> If you wish to make a nomination, please send the following  to Box 1958 by 4:00 pm on current nomination deadline date:</p>
<ul>
<li>thesis  adviserâs evaluation</li>
<li>a  copy of the thesis</li>
</ul>
<p>The Ruth Simmons Prize carries with it an award of $1,000.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/Simmons%20prize%20recipients_4.pdf">Full list of recipients of the Ruth Simmons Prize in Gender and Women's Studies</a></p>
<p class="style1"><strong><a name="Abey"></a>Congratulations to the 2017 Ruth Simmons Prize  recipient<br /></strong></p>
<p class="style1"><strong>Rebecca Hansen<br /></strong>Department of English<br />Nonfiction Writing Honors Program</p>
<p class="style1"><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-left" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Rebecca Hansen.thumbnail.jpeg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></p>
<p class="style1">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="style1">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="style1"><strong><br /><br /></strong><em>"On Coming Forward"</em></p>
<p class="style1"><em>On Coming Forward</em>&nbsp;parses our relationship to shared, public narratives of pain, from a 1682 Puritan captivity narrative to the artwork of Emma Sulkowicz. Hansen interrogates the notion that such narratives necessarily serve a therapeutic or progressive function, arguing instead that they often reinforce the existing social ethos by framing injustice as a matter of personal, private trauma. In the end, Hansen seeks a new model for healing, one that does not require public testimony or social recognition.&nbsp;<em><br /></em></p>
<p class="style1"><em> </em></p>
<hr />
<p><em> </em></p>
<p><strong>Joan Wallach Scott Prize</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center for Teaching and Research on Women annually  awards the Joan Wallach Scott Prize for an outstanding honors thesis in  Gender and Sexuality Studies. Joan Wallach Scott is the Harold F. Linder  Professor of Social Science at the Institute for Advanced Study. Among  her many books are <span style="text-decoration:underline">Gender and the Politics of History</span> (1988), <span style="text-decoration:underline">Only Paradoxes to Offer: French Feminists and the Rights of Man</span> (1996), <span style="text-decoration:underline">ParitÃ©: Sexual Equality and the Crisis of</span> <span style="text-decoration:underline">French Universalism</span> (2005), and <span style="text-decoration:underline">The Politics of the Veil</span>: <span style="text-decoration:underline">Banning Islamic Headscarves in French Public Schools</span> (2007). Professor Scott taught at Brown from 1980-1985, where she was  Nancy Duke Lewis Professor and Professor of History. She was the  founding director of the Pembroke Center.</p>
<p>Each year the Pembroke Center awards this prize for an outstanding  thesis by a Gender and Sexuality Studies Concentrator.</p>
<p><a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/JWS%20prize%20recipients_1.pdf">Click for a list of all Joan Wallach Scott Prize recipients</a></p>
<div style="margin-left:40px"></div>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h3><strong><a name="gradprize"></a>For Graduate Students</strong></h3>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong> Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize</strong></p>
<p>The Pembroke Center for Teaching  and Research on Women annually awards the Marie J. Langlois Dissertation  Prize for an outstanding dissertation in the area of feminist studies.  Marie J. Langlois became a trustee emerita of the Corporation in 2007    having previously served as trustee and vice chancellor of the    University since 1998.&nbsp; She served as a member of the Board of Fellows    from 1992 to 1998, as a member of the Board of Trustees from 1980 to    1985, and as a trustee and treasurer of the University from 1988 to    1992. She received a bachelor of arts degree from Brown in 1964 and a    master of business administration degree from Harvard University in    1967. Ms. Langlois recently retired as managing director of Washington    Trust Investors, a division of Washington Trust Company.&nbsp; She currently    serves on the boards of directors of the Rhode Island Foundation,    Lifespan, Salve Regina University, Rhode Island Philharmonic and Music    School, and Rhode Island Public Radio.</p>
<p>Each year the Pembroke Center awards this prize for a  dissertation in areas related to gender studies or feminist analysis. If  you wish to nominate a dissertation, please send to Box 1958 by 4:00 pm on current  nomination deadline date (April 21):</p>
<ol></ol>
<ul>
<li>A nominating letter including a brief description of the dissertation</li>
<li>A letter of support from a second member of the dissertation committee</li>
<li>A copy of the dissertation</li>
</ul>
<p>The Marie J. Langlois Prize carries with it an award of $1,000.</p>
<p><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/Langlois%20Dissertation%20prize%20recipients_3.pdf">Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize recipients</a></p>
<p><strong><a name="Adler"></a>Congratulations to the 2017 Marie J. Langlois Dissertation Prize recipient</strong></p>
<p><strong><strong>Nicosia M. Shakes</strong><br /></strong>Africana Studies</p>
<p><span class="thumbnail-wrapper inline inline-none" style="width:108px;"><img src="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/images/Nicosia Shakes portrait.thumbnail.jpg" alt="" title=""  class="image image-thumbnail " width="100" height="100" /></span></p>
<p><em>âAfricana Womenâs Theatre as Activism: A Study of Sistren Theatre Collective, Jamaica and the Mothertongue Project, South Africaâ</em></p>
<p><span>The result of sixteen months of ethnographic research, Nicosia Shakesâ dissertation examines the activism of Sistren Theatre Collective in Jamaica and The Mothertongue Project in South Africa, two women-led organizations that use theatre to advocate for gender justice. Under the theoretical rubrics of Africana feminisms and activist aesthetics, Shakes analyzes how the two organizations transgress interlocking systems of gender, racial, sexual, and economic domination. She argues that Sistren and The Mothertongue exemplify the global interconnections between feminist activism and theory.</span></p>
<hr />
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p><strong>Helen Terry MacLeod Prize</strong></p>
<p>From 1995-2007 the Pembroke Center awarded this prize for an  outstanding undergraduate honors thesis that addressed questions of  gender or women, or that brought a feminist analysis to bear on a topic  of study.</p>
<p><a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/uploads/MacLeodPrizeRecipients.pdf">MacLeod Prize recipients 1995-2007 </a></p>
<p>In 2007, this award was changed from a prize for a completed  honors thesis to a research grant available to support undergraduate  honors research. <a href="/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/research-grants-and-internships" title="Research Grants and Internships" rel="nofollow">See the grants page for more information.</a><span class="highlight">&nbsp;</span></p>

	<div id="pembroke-center" class="clear-block block block-menu ">
	
	<h5>Pembroke Center</h5>	
		<div class="content"><ul class="menu"><li class="leaf first menu-courses"><a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/courses-manual" title="">Courses</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-fellowships"><a href="http://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/research-pembroke-center/2013-14-pembroke-research-seminar" title="">Fellowships</a></li>
<li class="leaf menu-journal"><a href="http://brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/journal" title="">Journal</a></li>

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Gender and Sexuality Studies Affiliated Faculty</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-201" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p><strong><a href="http://biomed.brown.edu/facultydirectory/profile.php?id=1100923626">Susan Allen, Emerita</a></strong><br />Professor Emerita of Health Services, Policy, and Practice<br /> <a href="mailto:Susan_Allen@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Susan_Allen@brown.edu</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://www.watsoninstitute.org/contacts_detail.cfm?id=904" rel="nofollow">Shiva Balaghi</a></strong><br />Visiting Assitant Professor of Middle East Studies   <br /> <a href="mailto:Shiva_Balaghi@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Shiva_Balaghi@brown.edu</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://brown.edu/Departments/History/people/facultypage.php?id=1106970215">Omer Bartov</a></strong><br />Professor  of History and German Studies<br /> <a href="mailto:Omer_Bartov@Brown.EDU" rel="nofollow">Omer_Bartov@Brown.EDU</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://brown.edu/Departments/Comparative_Literature/people/facultypage.php?id=10108">Reda Bensmaia, Emeritus</a></strong><br />Professor Emeritus  of French Studies and Comparative Literature<br /> <a href="mailto:Reda_Bensmaia@Brown.EDU" rel="nofollow">Reda_Bensmaia@Brown.EDU</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Departments/Comparative_Literature/people/facultypage.php?id=10046">Susan Bernstein</a></strong><br />Professor  of Comparative Literature and German Studies<br /> <a href="mailto:Susan_Bernstein@Brown.EDU" rel="nofollow">Susan_Bernstein@Brown.EDU</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Departments/English/faculty/facultypage.php?id=10001">Timothy Bewes</a></strong><br />Professor of English<a href="mailto:Timothy_Bewes@Brown.EDU" rel="nofollow"><br /> Timothy_Bewes@Brown.EDU</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://brown.edu/Departments/Political_Science/faculty/facultypage.php?id=1250007608">Mark Blyth</a></strong><br />Professor  of Political Science<br /> <a href="mailto:Mark_Blyth@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Mark_Blyth@brown.edu</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://brown.edu/Departments/Africana_Studies/people/bogues_anthony.html">Anthony Bogues</a></strong><br />Professor  of Africana Studies<br /> <a href="mailto:Barrymore_Bogues@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Barrymore_Bogues@Brown.EDU</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://brown.edu/Departments/Medieval_Studies/people/facultypage.php?id=10267">Sheila Bonde </a></strong><br />Professor of History of Art and Architecture and Archaeology of the Ancient World<br /> <a href="mailto:Sheila_Bonde@Brown.EDU" rel="nofollow">Sheila_Bonde@Brown.EDU</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://brown.edu/Departments/Visual_Art/faculty/facultypage.php?id=10349">Leslie  Bostrom</a></strong><br />Professor of Visual Art<br /> <a href="mailto:Leslie_Bostrom@Brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Leslie_Bostrom@Brown.EDU</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://brown.edu/Departments/Africana_Studies/people/braun_lundy.html">Lundy  Braun</a></strong><br />Professor of Medical  Science and Africana Studies<br /> <a href="mailto:Lundy_Braun@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Lundy_Braun@Brown.EDU</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Departments/History/people/facultypage.php?id=1253195453">Cynthia  Brokaw</a></strong><br />Professor of History<br /> <a href="mailto:Cynthia_Brokaw@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Cynthia_Brokaw@brown.edu</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Departments/Anthropology/people/facultypage.php?id=1106970271">Keith Brown</a></strong><br />Professor of International Studies <br /> <a href="mailto:Keith_Brown@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Keith_Brown@Brown.EDU</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://brown.edu/Departments/Medieval_Studies/people/facultypage.php?id=10004">Elizabeth Johnson Bryan</a></strong><br />Associate Professor of  English<br /> <a href="mailto:Elizabeth_Bryan@Brown.EDU" rel="nofollow">Elizabeth_Bryan@Brown.EDU</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://brown.edu/Departments/Pembroke_Center/instruction/facultypage.php?id=10077facultypage.php?id=10077">Mari Jo Buhle, Emerita </a></strong><br />Professor Emerita of American Studies<br /> <a href="mailto:Mari_Buhle@Brown.EDU" rel="nofollow">Mari_Buhle@Brown.EDU</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://pembrokecenter.org/instruction/facultypage.php?id=1127248365" rel="nofollow">Caroline Castiglione</a></strong><br />Associate Professor of  Italian Studies<br /> <a href="mailto:Caroline_Castiglione@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Caroline_Castiglione@brown.edu</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Departments/MCM/people/facultypage.php?id=10109">Wendy Hui Kyong Chun</a></strong><br />Professor of Modern Culture and Media and History of Art and Architecture<br /> <a href="mailto:Wendy_Hui_Kyong_Chun@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Wendy_Hui_Kyong_Chun@Brown.EDU</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Departments/Religious_Studies/grad/facultypage.php?id=10126">Mark Cladis</a></strong><br />Professor of Religious Studies<br /> <a href="mailto:Mark_Cladis@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Mark_Cladis@brown.edu</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://brown.edu/Departments/Sarah_Doyle_Center/people/gail_cohee.html">Gail Cohee</a></strong><br />Director,  Sarah Doyle Womenâs Center<br /> <a href="mailto:Gail_Cohee@Brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Gail_Cohee@Brown.edu</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Departments/Political_Science/faculty/facultypage.php?id=1106970252">Linda Cook</a></strong><br />Professor of Political Science<br /> <a href="mailto:Linda_Cook@Brown.EDU" rel="nofollow">Linda_Cook@Brown.EDU</a></p>

<p><strong><a href="http://www.brown.edu/Departments/Comparative_Literature/people/facultypage.php?id=10056">Esther Whitfield</a></strong><br />Associate Professor of Comparative Literature and Hispanic Studies<br /> <a href="mailto:Esther_Whitfield@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Esther_Whitfield@Brown.EDU</a></p>
<p><strong><a href="http://brown.edu/Departments/Theatre_Speech_Dance/people/ybarra.html">Patricia Ybarra</a></strong><br />Associate Professor of  Theatre Arts and&nbsp; Performance Studies<br /> <a href="mailto:Patricia_Ybarra@brown.edu" rel="nofollow">Patricia_Ybarra@brown.edu</a></p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
							</div>

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Gender and Sexuality Studies Board</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-199" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>Drew Walker, Gender and Sexuality Studies, Chair<br /><br />FranÃ§oise Hamlin, Africana Studies; History<br />Lynne       Joyrich, Modern Culture and Media<br />E.       Tamar Katz, English, Urban Studies<br />Jacques       Khalip, English<br />Keisha-Khan Perry, Africana Studies<br />Richard Rambuss, English<br />Suzanne       Stewart-Steinberg, Comparative Literature; Italian Studies; Modern Culture and Media<br />Debbie Weinstein, American Studies</p>
<p>Ex Officio:</p>
<p>Gail Cohee, Sarah Doyle Women's Center<br />Denise Davis, Gender and Sexuality Studies</p>
  </div>

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Gender and Sexuality Studies Departmental Undergraduate Group (DUG)</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-198" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p>The Gender and Sexuality Studies Departmental Undergraduate  Group  (DUG) encourages all current and prospective concentrators to  participate  in its events and gatherings.&nbsp; The  DUG hosts an annual  fall concentration open house and sponsors lectures, study  breaks, and  other activities throughout the year.&nbsp; It is a good way to learn more  about this lively  concentration and meet other students with common  intellectual interests.&nbsp;</p>
<p>2016-17 DUG Leader: Sage Fanucchi-Funes</p>
<p><a href="https://listserv.brown.edu/?A0=GNSSDUG&amp;X=44AC2352FCE681401B">Join the GNSS DUG Listserv</a></p>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->
						
													<div id="sidebar-left" class="sidebar first-column column">

</ul></div>
			
				
	</div>


	
	<div id="block-brown_social_media-0" class="clear-block block block-brown_social_media ">

		<title>Honors in Gender and Sexuality Studies | Pembroke Center for Teaching and Research on Women</title>

		<ul class="access">
			<li><a href="#body-content" accesskey="s" tabindex="1">Skip navigation</a></li>

		<div class="wrapper">

<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Honors in Gender and Sexuality Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-197" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p class="large"><strong>Applying for Honors in Gender and Sexuality Studies  (GNSS)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/honors-gender-and-sexuality-studies#requirements"><span class="large"><span class="small">Requirements</span></span></a><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/honors-gender-and-sexuality-studies#ThesisAdvisors"><span class="large"><span class="small"></span></span><span class="large"><span class="small"></span></span></a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/honors-gender-and-sexuality-studies#ThesisAdvisors"><span class="large"><span class="small">Role of Thesis Advisors and Readers</span></span></a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/honors-gender-and-sexuality-studies#ThesisAdvisors"><span class="large"><span class="small"></span></span><span class="large"><span class="small"></span></span></a><a href="#writingtools" rel="nofollow">Useful Writing and Editing Tools</a></li>
</ul>
<p>In order to qualify for honors, a student must be a GNSS concentrator who has earned a B+ average in overall coursework. Students who have received a grade of NC in any concentration course  will not be admitted to the program save in exceptional circumstances. Candidates should discuss  their plans  with the programâs director during their sixth semester and  should submit their  honors proposal by the end of their sixth semester  or no later than the  beginning of their seventh semester.</p>
<p>In  order to apply, a student should submit a 3-5 page proposal to  the program  director and have found an advisor appropriate to the  project. The proposal  should include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Cover sheet with studentâs name, email address, advisorâs name, and  proposed thesis title,</li>
<li>Discussion of the main questions that the thesis will address, the   methodological and theoretical approaches that the student plans to  use, and  the research that will form the basis for the thesis, and</li>
<li>Preliminary bibliography of primary and secondary sources.</li>
</ul>
<p class="large"><strong><a name="requirements"></a>Requirements</strong></p>
<p>Honors  concentrators take all of the courses required for a GNSS  concentrator, plus  GNSS 1970 and 1980 (thesis writing courses) during  their senior year. During the fall of senior year, honors  concentrators  must enroll in GNSS 1970 and 1990 (the Senior Seminar), and they  must  enroll in GNSS 1980 in the spring.  Their advisor will grade 1970 and  1980, while the Senior Seminar  instructor will grade 1990.  Students  may submit overlapping written work to GNSS 1970 and 1990, but  the  concentration expects students to conduct enough substantially distinct   work for each (e.g. course readings, presentations, and peer review in  Senior  seminar and thesis outline, research, and additional writing in  1970) to  warrant credit for two courses.</p>
<p>By  the end of the fall semester reading period, the student will  turn in a  significant piece of written work (typically one chapter, but  to be determined  in each case in consultation with the studentâs  advisor). By that time, the  student will also have produced a  well-developed, detailed outline or otherwise  have a substantial  framing for the overall project, as well as have significant  research  completed. The advisor  will submit a brief progress report on the  status of the thesis to the  concentration director at the end of the  fall semester.</p>
<p>A  full draft of the thesis must be submitted to the advisor and  reader by  mid-March. The completed thesis must be submitted to the  advisor and second  reader by mid-April. If the advisor and second  reader deem the thesis to be of  superior quality, the candidate will be  awarded the designation of Honors in  Gender and Sexuality Studies. If  the readers judge the thesis acceptable but  not of honors caliber, the  student will receive credit for the full  two-semesters of work.<br /> <strong>&nbsp;</strong></p>
<p class="large"><strong><a name="ThesisAdvisors"></a>Role of Thesis Advisors and Readers</strong></p>
<p>At the beginning of the fall semester, students should discuss   expectations for regular meetings, written work, and deadlines with  their  advisor. A second reader for the thesis must be in place no later  than the end  of the studentâs seventh semester. The second readerâs  role is to provide  supplementary guidance and feedback on the studentâs  research and writing, the  extent of which will be individually  determined. Both the primary advisor and  the secondary reader will read  the final version of the thesis and submit  written feedback to the  concentration and the student.</p>
<p>Thesis advisors should:</p>
<ul>
<li>Establish work schedules and help set deadlines for completed work</li>
<li>Meet with advisee on regular basis</li>
<li>Help advisee plan and organize research</li>
<li>Read research reports and drafts of chapters</li>
<li>Submit a progress report at the end of the fall semester to the  concentration advisor</li>
<li>Read full draft of thesis submitted in mid-March and provide  comments for revisions to the thesis writer</li>
<li>Submit written evaluation of the final thesis to the concentration  advisor by late April. </li>
</ul>
<p>Thesis readers should:</p>
<ul>
<li>Meet with advisee on an as-needed basis</li>
<li>May help advisee plan and organize research</li>
<li>May read drafts of chapters</li>
<li>Read full draft of thesis submitted in mid-March and provide comments for revisions to the thesis writer</li>
<li>Submit written evaluation of the final thesis to the concentration advisor by late April.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
</ul>
<p class="large"><strong><a name="writingtools"></a>Useful Writing and Editing Tools for Honors Thesis Writers</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://libguides.brown.edu/gender">Brown University GNSS LibGuide</a></li>
<li>How to Write a BA Thesis: A Practical Guide from Your First Ideas to Your Finished Paper<br /> by Charles Lipson<a href="http://site.ebrary.com.revproxy.brown.edu/lib/brown/Doc?id=10216904"><br />Full text via Brown Library<br /> </a><a href="http://www.charleslipson.com/How-to-write-a-thesis.htm" rel="nofollow">Online summary</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.crockford.com/wrrrld/style.html" rel="nofollow">The Elements of Style</a><br /> By William Strunk, Jr.</li>
<li><a href="http://josiah.brown.edu/record=b4112764%7ES7">Chicago Manual of Style </a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.bedfordstmartins.com/online/citex.html" rel="nofollow">How to Cite Online Sources</a><br /> by Andrew Harnack and Eugene Kleppinger</li>
</ul>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

	</div>

</article>

			<section id="banner" class="marginator sub-banner" style="background-image:url(/research/pembroke-center/sites/brown.edu.research.pembroke-center/files/ursa_minor_simple_banner_image.jpg); height:200px;">
