<!-- Layout -->

				<div id="content">
					<div class="marginator">
					
					

									
					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Honors in Gender and Sexuality Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-197" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p class="large"><strong>Applying for Honors in Gender and Sexuality Studies  (GNSS)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/honors-gender-and-sexuality-studies#requirements"><span class="large"><span class="small">Requirements</span></span></a><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/honors-gender-and-sexuality-studies#ThesisAdvisors"><span class="large"><span class="small"></span></span><span class="large"><span class="small"></span></span></a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/honors-gender-and-sexuality-studies#ThesisAdvisors"><span class="large"><span class="small">Role of Thesis Advisors and Readers</span></span></a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/honors-gender-and-sexuality-studies#ThesisAdvisors"><span class="large"><span class="small"></span></span><span class="large"><span class="small"></span></span></a><a href="#writingtools" rel="nofollow">Useful Writing and Editing Tools</a></li>
</ul>
<p>In order to qualify for honors, a student must be a GNSS concentrator who has earned a B+ average in overall coursework. Students who have received a grade of NC in any concentration course  will not be admitted to the program save in exceptional circumstances. Candidates should discuss  their plans  with the programâs director during their sixth semester and  should submit their  honors proposal by the end of their sixth semester  or no later than the  beginning of their seventh semester.</p>
<p>In  order to apply, a student should submit a 3-5 page proposal to  the program  director and have found an advisor appropriate to the  project. The proposal  should include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Cover sheet with studentâs name, email address, advisorâs name, and  proposed thesis title,</li>
<li>Discussion of the main questions that the thesis will address, the   methodological and theoretical approaches that the student plans to  use, and  the research that will form the basis for the thesis, and</li>
<li>Preliminary bibliography of primary and secondary sources.</li>
</ul>
<p class="large"><strong><a name="requirements"></a>Requirements</strong></p>
<p>Honors  concentrators take all of the courses required for a GNSS  concentrator, plus  GNSS 1970 and 1980 (thesis writing courses) during  their senior year. During the fall of senior year, honors  concentrators  must enroll in GNSS 1970 and 1990 (the Senior Seminar), and they  must  enroll in GNSS 1980 in the spring.  Their advisor will grade 1970 and  1980, while the Senior Seminar  instructor will grade 1990.  Students  may submit overlapping written work to GNSS 1970 and 1990, but  the  concentration expects students to conduct enough substantially distinct   work for each (e.g. course readings, presentations, and peer review in  Senior  seminar and thesis outline, research, and additional writing in  1970) to  warrant credit for two courses.</p>
<p>By  the end of the fall semester reading period, the student will  turn in a  significant piece of written work (typically one chapter, but  to be determined  in each case in consultation with the studentâs  advisor). By that time, the  student will also have produced a  well-developed, detailed outline or otherwise  have a substantial  framing for the overall project, as well as have significant  research  completed. The advisor  will submit a brief progress report on the  status of the thesis to the  concentration director at the end of the  fall semester.</p>
<p>A  full draft of the thesis must be submitted to the advisor and  reader by  mid-March. The completed thesis must be submitted to the  advisor and second  reader by mid-April. If the advisor and second  reader deem the thesis to be of  superior quality, the candidate will be  awarded the designation of Honors in  Gender and Sexuality Studies. If  the readers judge the thesis acceptable but  not of honors caliber, the  student will receive credit for the full  two-semesters of work.<br /> <strong>&nbsp;</strong></p>
<p class="large"><strong><a name="ThesisAdvisors"></a>Role of Thesis Advisors and Readers</strong></p>
<p>At the beginning of the fall semester, students should discuss   expectations for regular meetings, written work, and deadlines with  their  advisor. A second reader for the thesis must be in place no later  than the end  of the studentâs seventh semester. The second readerâs  role is to provide  supplementary guidance and feedback on the studentâs  research and writing, the  extent of which will be individually  determined. Both the primary advisor and  the secondary reader will read  the final version of the thesis and submit  written feedback to the  concentration and the student.</p>
<p>Thesis advisors should:</p>
<ul>
<li>Establish work schedules and help set deadlines for completed work</li>
<li>Meet with advisee on regular basis</li>
<li>Help advisee plan and organize research</li>
<li>Read research reports and drafts of chapters</li>
<li>Submit a progress report at the end of the fall semester to the  concentration advisor</li>
<li>Read full draft of thesis submitted in mid-March and provide  comments for revisions to the thesis writer</li>
<li>Submit written evaluation of the final thesis to the concentration  advisor by late April. </li>
</ul>
<p>Thesis readers should:</p>
<ul>
<li>Meet with advisee on an as-needed basis</li>
<li>May help advisee plan and organize research</li>
<li>May read drafts of chapters</li>
<li>Read full draft of thesis submitted in mid-March and provide comments for revisions to the thesis writer</li>
<li>Submit written evaluation of the final thesis to the concentration advisor by late April.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
</ul>
<p class="large"><strong><a name="writingtools"></a>Useful Writing and Editing Tools for Honors Thesis Writers</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://libguides.brown.edu/gender">Brown University GNSS LibGuide</a></li>
<li>How to Write a BA Thesis: A Practical Guide from Your First Ideas to Your Finished Paper<br /> by Charles Lipson<a href="http://site.ebrary.com.revproxy.brown.edu/lib/brown/Doc?id=10216904"><br />Full text via Brown Library<br /> </a><a href="http://www.charleslipson.com/How-to-write-a-thesis.htm" rel="nofollow">Online summary</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.crockford.com/wrrrld/style.html" rel="nofollow">The Elements of Style</a><br /> By William Strunk, Jr.</li>
<li><a href="http://josiah.brown.edu/record=b4112764%7ES7">Chicago Manual of Style </a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.bedfordstmartins.com/online/citex.html" rel="nofollow">How to Cite Online Sources</a><br /> by Andrew Harnack and Eugene Kleppinger</li>
</ul>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

			
	    
		</div><!-- end .meta -->
	</div>

</article>
							</div>

							
													</div><!-- end .second-column -->

				<div id="content">

					<div class="columns main-columns">

						<h1 class="article-title  with-tabs">Honors in Gender and Sexuality Studies</h1>
						
						

						<div id="body-content" class="second-column column main-column">

							
																												
							
							<div class="clear-block">
								
<article id="node-197" class="main-article node">








  <div class="content">
        <p class="large"><strong>Applying for Honors in Gender and Sexuality Studies  (GNSS)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/honors-gender-and-sexuality-studies#requirements"><span class="large"><span class="small">Requirements</span></span></a><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/honors-gender-and-sexuality-studies#ThesisAdvisors"><span class="large"><span class="small"></span></span><span class="large"><span class="small"></span></span></a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/honors-gender-and-sexuality-studies#ThesisAdvisors"><span class="large"><span class="small">Role of Thesis Advisors and Readers</span></span></a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.brown.edu/research/pembroke-center/undergraduate-concentration-gender-and-sexuality-studies/honors-gender-and-sexuality-studies#ThesisAdvisors"><span class="large"><span class="small"></span></span><span class="large"><span class="small"></span></span></a><a href="#writingtools" rel="nofollow">Useful Writing and Editing Tools</a></li>
</ul>
<p>In order to qualify for honors, a student must be a GNSS concentrator who has earned a B+ average in overall coursework. Students who have received a grade of NC in any concentration course  will not be admitted to the program save in exceptional circumstances. Candidates should discuss  their plans  with the programâs director during their sixth semester and  should submit their  honors proposal by the end of their sixth semester  or no later than the  beginning of their seventh semester.</p>
<p>In  order to apply, a student should submit a 3-5 page proposal to  the program  director and have found an advisor appropriate to the  project. The proposal  should include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Cover sheet with studentâs name, email address, advisorâs name, and  proposed thesis title,</li>
<li>Discussion of the main questions that the thesis will address, the   methodological and theoretical approaches that the student plans to  use, and  the research that will form the basis for the thesis, and</li>
<li>Preliminary bibliography of primary and secondary sources.</li>
</ul>
<p class="large"><strong><a name="requirements"></a>Requirements</strong></p>
<p>Honors  concentrators take all of the courses required for a GNSS  concentrator, plus  GNSS 1970 and 1980 (thesis writing courses) during  their senior year. During the fall of senior year, honors  concentrators  must enroll in GNSS 1970 and 1990 (the Senior Seminar), and they  must  enroll in GNSS 1980 in the spring.  Their advisor will grade 1970 and  1980, while the Senior Seminar  instructor will grade 1990.  Students  may submit overlapping written work to GNSS 1970 and 1990, but  the  concentration expects students to conduct enough substantially distinct   work for each (e.g. course readings, presentations, and peer review in  Senior  seminar and thesis outline, research, and additional writing in  1970) to  warrant credit for two courses.</p>
<p>By  the end of the fall semester reading period, the student will  turn in a  significant piece of written work (typically one chapter, but  to be determined  in each case in consultation with the studentâs  advisor). By that time, the  student will also have produced a  well-developed, detailed outline or otherwise  have a substantial  framing for the overall project, as well as have significant  research  completed. The advisor  will submit a brief progress report on the  status of the thesis to the  concentration director at the end of the  fall semester.</p>
<p>A  full draft of the thesis must be submitted to the advisor and  reader by  mid-March. The completed thesis must be submitted to the  advisor and second  reader by mid-April. If the advisor and second  reader deem the thesis to be of  superior quality, the candidate will be  awarded the designation of Honors in  Gender and Sexuality Studies. If  the readers judge the thesis acceptable but  not of honors caliber, the  student will receive credit for the full  two-semesters of work.<br /> <strong>&nbsp;</strong></p>
<p class="large"><strong><a name="ThesisAdvisors"></a>Role of Thesis Advisors and Readers</strong></p>
<p>At the beginning of the fall semester, students should discuss   expectations for regular meetings, written work, and deadlines with  their  advisor. A second reader for the thesis must be in place no later  than the end  of the studentâs seventh semester. The second readerâs  role is to provide  supplementary guidance and feedback on the studentâs  research and writing, the  extent of which will be individually  determined. Both the primary advisor and  the secondary reader will read  the final version of the thesis and submit  written feedback to the  concentration and the student.</p>
<p>Thesis advisors should:</p>
<ul>
<li>Establish work schedules and help set deadlines for completed work</li>
<li>Meet with advisee on regular basis</li>
<li>Help advisee plan and organize research</li>
<li>Read research reports and drafts of chapters</li>
<li>Submit a progress report at the end of the fall semester to the  concentration advisor</li>
<li>Read full draft of thesis submitted in mid-March and provide  comments for revisions to the thesis writer</li>
<li>Submit written evaluation of the final thesis to the concentration  advisor by late April. </li>
</ul>
<p>Thesis readers should:</p>
<ul>
<li>Meet with advisee on an as-needed basis</li>
<li>May help advisee plan and organize research</li>
<li>May read drafts of chapters</li>
<li>Read full draft of thesis submitted in mid-March and provide comments for revisions to the thesis writer</li>
<li>Submit written evaluation of the final thesis to the concentration advisor by late April.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
</ul>
<p class="large"><strong><a name="writingtools"></a>Useful Writing and Editing Tools for Honors Thesis Writers</strong></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="http://libguides.brown.edu/gender">Brown University GNSS LibGuide</a></li>
<li>How to Write a BA Thesis: A Practical Guide from Your First Ideas to Your Finished Paper<br /> by Charles Lipson<a href="http://site.ebrary.com.revproxy.brown.edu/lib/brown/Doc?id=10216904"><br />Full text via Brown Library<br /> </a><a href="http://www.charleslipson.com/How-to-write-a-thesis.htm" rel="nofollow">Online summary</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.crockford.com/wrrrld/style.html" rel="nofollow">The Elements of Style</a><br /> By William Strunk, Jr.</li>
<li><a href="http://josiah.brown.edu/record=b4112764%7ES7">Chicago Manual of Style </a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.bedfordstmartins.com/online/citex.html" rel="nofollow">How to Cite Online Sources</a><br /> by Andrew Harnack and Eugene Kleppinger</li>
</ul>
  </div>

	



  <div class="clear-block">
    <div class="meta">

	</div>

</article>

    </div>
  
  
  
  
  
  
</div> </div>
			
				
	</div>

							</div>
						
					</div><!-- end .columns -->

											<div id="sidebar-right" class="sidebar third-column column">
							
	
	<div id="calendar" class="clear-block block block-calwidget ">
	
	<h2>Calendar</h2>	
		<div class="content"><section class="events-list">
      <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Oct        </span>
        <span class="day">
          20        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  even">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b2132b0-000007c2events%40brown.edu/">Mid-semester deadline. Last day to change from credit to audit in a course (5:00 p.m. deadline).</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Oct        </span>
        <span class="day">
          23        </span></h5>
        <ul>
              <li class="event  odd">
            <a href="http://events.brown.edu/events/cal/CAL-00147cc4-5539568d-0155-3b2276fb-00000c48events%40brown.edu/">Advising period for spring pre-registration. Students in their first through third semesters will need to procure their advising PIN from their advisor in order to register.</a>
          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">
        <h5><span class="month day-of-the-week">
          Nov        </span>

          02        </span></h5>

          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>
            <div class="date">

          </li>
            </div><!-- end .date -->
        </ul>

							<div id="breadcrumbs"><ul>	<li class="first"><span class="a">Page not found</span></li></ul></div>					</nav>
				</div>

			</header>
